content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Eador is a good alternative strategy game to people who are weary of Civilization and its clones, once all the bugs are gone (most of them should be in 2016).It is similar to the old Heroes of Might and Magic and Disciples series, moving units of fantasy setting on a grid battle.Previously, after 300 hours spent in the game, I encountered a game-breaking bug that prevented me from finishing the game. Understandably I was upset and didn't want to write a review. Now after a second attempt at just a meager 50+ hours, the bug didn't occur and I completed the game the way I wanted it.The campaign has multiple endings, and it is a clever way to keep you playing over and over, although it can be long-winded and tedious.The dialogue is often humorous and the various Masters you meet are just as colourful.Eador is a good strategy game to get at a discount.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Eador: Master of the broken world is an indie strategy game developed by Snowbird Games. Eador is one of those games that makes you think deeply before buying and keeps you indecisive when it comes to decisions. It is a great game yet in the same time it isn’t. The game starts with an amazing cinematic which shows you as a god capable of taking decisions for humanity while ignoring morality. Initially, the first impression I had of Eador was extremely negative when it came to gameplay. The game has been up since 2013 and yet it is still plagued with bugs and issues. During my first hour of gameplay, I had dealt with two game breaking bugs and three crashes. On the top of that, the game was lagging insanely even though the recommended settings are Intel Core 2 duo 1.6 and a GeForce 8800 for the graphic card. As a proud owner of an I7 4720M with a Geforce GTX 960M 4 GB I figured the game would work perfectly. Luckyly, after surfing the forums I was able to minimize the crashes and the bugs amount by turning off shadow maps option and enabling simplified combat. It also completely removed the ‘’lag’’ effect which made the game ten times more enjoyable.At its core Eador looks similar to heroes and might and magic series, but plays very differently. At the very beginning you can start with one of the four heroes, each completely customizable with its own abilities which are either beneficial in battles or on the grid map. The choices are warrior, scout, commander and wizard. Those heroes can be recruited multiple times if you have the resources and act as your commanders. Those heroes can be further customized with gear bought in the stores built in your main castle, stores found by exploring or from adventures. Furthermore, the heroes can be also equipped with different spells to use which can either be bought in the magic guilds built in the capital or found on adventures. The commanders also have divergent paths at level 10, which gives them four choices and unique abilities for each choice. A scout becoming a ranger for instance will shot two arrows in the same turn. A warrior becoming a dark knight will be able to heal when it kills enemies. Each of those choices further diversify the pool of customization in EadorThe construction menu in Eador is also unique. Unlike most games, you only have one city and the rest are classified as settlements populated by humans, orcs, halflings, centaurs, dwarves, barbarians, goblins and other races. Some of those settlements even grant unique buildings when you engage in an alliance. The building system itself is complex since there are 10 types of categories in terms of buildings which go from tier 1 up to tier 4. Some of those buildings also feature a karma system and either give positive points or negative ones which affect the events happening in the game The game also has a nice dynamic system where events can happen in provinces and can be influenced depending on the decision you take. In one of those instances a group of adventurers claimed loot from one of my provinces and I decided to ask them for half of it. The group refused so I set the militia on them which resulted in their demise and my gain of two artifacts. Those events give even more flavor to the game and make it a lot more enjoyable.In terms of combat, Eador is an unforgiving turn-based game. In fact, it’s characterized by unique features such as the tiles having different elements (plains/forests/swamps/hills) which give different bonuses or negative effects but also by the stamina and morale of the units. The stamina stat determines how many actions the unit has including movement, attacks and spellcasting while morale usually determines the damage, but also makes the unit flee if it reaches 0 which can make battles quite interesting. Many players have complained of Eador’s difficulty since it is definitely not for the ones weak at heart.Overall, Eador is a game that can be enjoyed if you can get past its quirks, bugs and crashes. The game comes with an autosave every turn up to 4 turns so you can always reload pretty fast. The game deserves a 7/10 and I recommend to those who enjoy hard strategy turn-based games.For our popular daily giveaways and similar reviews head over to http://www.steamified.com/To begin your journey through our myriad of social media join our Steam Group

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												A very fun turn based 4x fantasy based strategy game.Dangerously addictive game. Hours just melt away playing this game.It's not an easy game, definately not for casual players. Build order for buildings is very important. You have to balance available money between buying new units and building new buildings/province improvements. Units require monetary or gem upkeep, some require both. Build too many units and you cannot improve provinces or build castle improvments. If you spend too much time improving your castle and provinces the AI will steamroll you with thier army. So a carefull balance between economy and military buildup is necessary.Negative: AI does not calculate battles well. Battles that will destroy your entire army on auto will be listed as being very easy. Battles listed as too difficult are easy to win in manual mode. So most battles will have to be fought in manual, since even in very easy battles you will lose units (possibly even powerfull units) if these easy battles are fought on auto.Pros: Good replayability. Map generator is similar to the civilization games. Large or small shards can be generated depending on desired length of time you want to play in a skirmish.The Campaign is a good way to learn the game, but is very long. I played the campaign just long enought to get the game basics down.Many different unit types available, good, evil, or neutral. As well as magical or mundane units.Overall a very fun game. I would suggest setting an alarm clock before playing since hours can go by very rapidly. I started playing this game in the mornig, next thing I know it's 2pm. I missed breakfast and lunch. Recommended to 4x Strategy game fans.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Eador: Masters of the Broken World is the very definition of a "flawed gem". It's a brilliant turn-based strategy with classical "heroesque" tactical battles, solid stronghold and province management component and profound RPG systems on top of that all. Add to that a uniquely structured campaign (albeit a one that's a bit too long to my liking) in an interesting charming setting with a good deal of both humour and seriousness. Imagine if Heroes of Might and Magic and Master of Magic had an illegitimate child. That's pretty much what Eador is. Sounds utterly fantastic, right? If only that was the whole deal.Unfortunately not everything is sunshine and roses. Masters of the Broken World is actually a sort of a remake and a sequel, all-in-one. It took the great gameplay mix described above straight from its predecessor - Eador: Genesis. The idea was to greatly enhance the graphical appearance of the game with tons of *shinies* and stuff. Too bad it didn't really work out as planned. The new graphics aren't ugly, even somewhat nice but mostly awkwardish. The interface was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mess at launch and although it got better with patches, it's still pretty clunky. Add to that the fact that despite all the updates the army of bugs is still undefeated to this day. To summarize: the game is fantastic at its core, it has one of the best gameplay in the genre, but the technical side of things leaves much to be desired. Be prepared to battle the interface and fend off nasty glitches and bugs. Having said that, I must stress once more that despite the shortcomings, the game itself is brilliant. Don't let yourself be frightened off by superficial things, embrace the addiction.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Easily the best "HOMM" type game I've played. HOMM is pretty much dead to me these days and I have no interest in the new version where you stack troops and faceroll boring maps for more story bits. I'm a bigger fan of the King's Bounty series but those are still largely about progression through troop stacks and a bit lacking in the grand scheme development. Eador however, is ALL about the development of your capital and all of the land around it. I was initially put off by the more story/objective driven campaign and didn't fully realize that this game did in fact have a sandbox mode, so I'm glad I gave it a second chance.The thing that really sets it off is that you'll take over bigger plots of land, but will have to fully explore it, clear all of the dungeons within it and completely run the enemy forces out of it before you actually gain the land making fights a lot more thoughtful than just single tile-grabbing. This process may not even be possible until you level up a bit higher and come back As in just because you walked on a tile doesn't mean you fully own and control it.  You are also fighting not only all of the monsters around the map, but also the AI building their capitals as well. Not to mention there's actually things on the maps like rocks and hills that you can USE. I took out a bigger army due to great placement with ranged units and chokepoints. That would NEVER happen in HOMM.Of course there's tons of tech tree type buildings and troops with upgrades and multiple classes of heros. It's your typical foray across a map, and the game itself does nothing brand new. It's just how it's glued together and operates that sets it apart. I picked this up for a fiver in a bundle at one point and I've seen it that low on a sale. If you like turn based strategy games you could do so much worse here for that price. It's another game that has 100's of hours potential going for it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												A decent turn-based strategy game with RPG elements. If you like games like Heroes of might and Magic, and Kings Bounty, this would definitely be a game to consider.PROSDoes what you would expect of the core elements very well.A lot of variety; units, weapons, tactics, etc.A lot of tactical debth.CONSNot for everyone, the lack of pace can be frustrating for some.There is a bit of a learning curve, especially for managing your city.AI balancing, it does cheat.If you like this type of games, and are a completionist to boot, you will be in for a long experience. The nature of progression makes your heroes start over each map/realm. And extensive possibilities of exploring provinces under your control makes it hard for you to decide weather to explore the land you have, or conquer more. And the AI tends to act in a Zerglike manner on the map if you dilly-dally too long. That being said, if you like games mentioned above there is a lot of hours of fun to get here.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Deciding whether to recommend this game was difficult. Eador has some rather nice ideas, and the difficulty scales relatively well into the game. I enjoy some of the mechanics, especially the way that hero classes are structured, skills can be chosen, and "prestige classes" are selected at later levels. I also like some of the more interesting units and the many choices in building up your stronghold. Having gems used as a global mana supply is also quite nice, and helps to balance mages.In the end though, there is still enough missing from the game that I can't outright recommend it. The graphics aren't great and the game has crashed on a number of occasions. When running it has a noticable effect on my computer's performance (I like to have a turn-based game open and play a turn or two between other tasks) both in terms of processor and memory.More seriously though, there are some issues with the gameplay. There doesn't appear to be a way to retreat from battles, and the battle level estimate algorithm is badly broken at times. I've had an army wiped when told that I should be able to win without casualties, and won some battles easily when they were meant to be difficult. Estimating the difficulty of the battle yourself is next to impossible - you know the unit types and total number, but not the exact composition or level. That last is especially important, since mis-judging the level of opposing units can make a huge difference. And since unit levels help so much, losing one or more units to a badly estimated battle is a big set-back.Another issue is that the battle maps don't particularly correspond to the supposed terrain. While there is some correspondence (for example if the area is deadlands then there's a bigger chance to get an appropriate battle map) you could end up being told that you're attacking a dungeon or hill and be fighting in a swamp-based map. This adds to the problem of judging battle difficulty.The graphics are OK but not brilliant. The music is quite nice, if repetitive. Luck can play a major part in a campaign. On my current campagin my first encounter was with a shop that sold (amongst other things) gargoyles, which really helped early on. I also had many free towns nearby, meaning I could gain provinces through bargaining even though those areas were really far too high level for me (and correspondingly increasing my early income).Quests and events are also a nice idea, but don't really work. When a centaur tells me that ogres have been raiding them from nearby hills and set me a task to kill some, I expect to actually find ogres in those hills. If spiders are repeatedly breeding in one of my provinces I'd expect to be able to send one of my heroes in to deal with them rather than having to pay some random adventuring party.In conclusion, those interested in turn-based fantasy games will probably find enough to make the purchase worthwhile, but will also find plenty of frustration. I'd love to see the game developed more, becaue it appears to be a great platform to build on.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												First off: this game is fun. If you like HOMM/AoW style combat and empire development, this will be right up your alley. It's a bit simpler (units don't have many spells/skills and mainly boil down to melee/archer/mage/healer), but not simple. As is typical for these types of games, the combat gets repetitive.Now, there's another Eador game, named Eador: Genesis. It's 99% the same game, but this one has (much) better graphics and some minor tweaks. However, MotBW also introduced some serious bugs, one of which is pretty game breaking. It's also a bit slower than ideal, especially on older systems. A lot of the gameplay revolves around reloading the game as a "go back in time" mechanic, mainly because of the inability to properly scout enemies and the impossibility to predict the actual strength of an army [unless you play the first or second difficulty, out of 7 or so]. Eador: Genesis is bug free and due to its age suffers no lag or delays. The "reload last turn" mechanic makes more sense there, but is also less forgiving than the full save/load in MotBW; to be hones it's much more interesting that way.So my advice would be to pick up Eador: Genesis ($6 on GOG.com I believe) unless you REALLY like flashy graphics in a tactics game.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Played about 7 hours. The problem is the game repeats the same fight over and over on the shards, and you find yourself just ignoring the stupid random messages that become an annoyance rather than fun. Add in the fact that there's almost no strategy to any of the game.Here's the strategy on how to win: Move as fast as you can to conquer sections. That's it. If you can do that, you win. It's another game that's more about rushing around than actual strategy, or building up defenses, or dealing with an economy that makes any sense. Add in the fact that the mood metrics of the game are very convoluted, and you end up with gameplay that you'll be trying to skip rather than playing.Eventually I just got so frustrated I gave up. It's trying to be HOMM with a bigger veneer on it, but it's nowhere near as fun. Shame, because if they fleshed out the overland map part, it could be fun. But it's completely unbalanced and as such it makes no sense.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												So, I've had a chance to play this game for a couple hours now... or 300, I guess. I do like it a lot, so I feel like I owe the game and the developers my feedback, which might help some people decide that they should get this! (or not, I suppose).Firstly, it's a turn based strategy game in a fantasy setting. Anyone who's a fan of that genre knows that it can be really difficult to tell a good one from a bad one by looking at screenshots on Steam. As a result, I own the complete collection of bad ones.I classify this game as good. For me personally, it's probably one of my favorite games, and would be in the shortlist of titles that I might choose from if I were forced to play only one game forever. Other titles in this "shortlist" might be Dominions 3, and Heroes of Might and Magic III. Now that 75% of you have stopped reading this, I can speak specifically to the people who should be reading this.Eador has a lot in common with those other two games I mentioned. Hiring heroes, outfitting them with gear and troops to roam the map conquering territory, building improvements in your castle, casting "adventure spells" and "combat spells" that you obtained from your buildings or looted scrolls. So many similarities, it captures all of the great things from the other games of this genre, so the decision whether to get this game hinges on what it does differently.First of all, the scale of the game is enormous. The campaign is the primary game mode. You choose a "shard", which is a piece of a broken world, they are all just floating around in space, and each one has a unique set of properties that will alter the rules of the game on that shard. One shard might have magically infused crystals, making wizardry especially effective, or a desert shard makes it difficult for troops to move across a battlefield, etc. The shards also have a "size" (map size), and a reward for conquering the shard. The rewards are mostly centered around unlocking castle improvements, which will then be available to you in subsequent shards. With the exception of previous shard rewards, nothing carries over between shards, as your "character" is just the immortal calling the shots from above, and he can only pass on what he has learned. The shards all have their own inhabitants and a unique ecosystem. In addition, there will be other immortals, like yourself, on the shard trying to capture it. You capture the shard by conquering the castles of these other immortals. The winning immortal has the shard merge into his master shard, (a collection of all his previously captured shards). You can choose to attack these master shards, where it will be a 1v1 battle between you and the immortal who owns it. If an immortal loses a game on his master shard, he is eliminated from the campaign altogether, and all of his rewards go to the person who defeated him. This is true for you as well, some immortals will attack your master shard, and losing means game over. Also keep in mind that while you are attacking shards, the other immortals are going after them as well. Some shards might get snapped up while you are battling on a different one, so prioritize them if they contain technology that is part of your fundamental strategy.All the while this is going on, there will be plenty of bantering, wheeling and dealing, smack talking, and good old fashioned back stabbing happening between the immortals. All of them want something from you, want you to hate the people they hate, or try to convert you to whatever their psychopathic vision might be for how the universe should operate. You can take them up on these things, and it can have a dramatic effect on the "storyline" of the game. You can kill them off if you choose, and they will do it to each other from time to time when the universe gets crowded. There are many of them, and more of them will keep springing up along the way, each with their own personality, back story, misguided morals, and gameplay strategies. The choices you make in game will affect their attitude toward you.It's important to understand the whole shard and immortal concept of the game because this is a big turn off for some people. Conquering a single shard is like playing an entire game from start to finish in any other strategy title, something that can take 1 to 12 hours, depending on the map size. Then you move on to the next shard where all your heroes are level 1 again, and all your phat loot is gone, and your castle has no upgrades again. While 95% of your time will be spent battling on shards, the overall story arc and meaningful strategic decisions will happen outside of them. This is what makes the game feel like it has nearly infinite possibilities and replay value for me, but I've heard others comment that moving from shard to shard feels punishing as you have to keep "starting over". You definitely need to decide which camp you fall in.The pace of the game is much slower and more nuanced than similar titles. You will be faced with MANY decisions in the game, and their impact is rarely immediate. These will come in the form of random events and encounters, where you will be making moral or monetary choices, which buildings you build will open other building possibilities while closing a bunch of others, and the troops you hire will have their own alignments and synergies. In a game like Heroes of Might and Magic, the outcome of the game might be decided on turn 9, by the guy who built his capital first, or captured the ultimate artifact, and the rest is just cleanup. In Eador, you build momentum. You pay 50 gold for +2 gold a turn, because in 30 turns, you're going to be glad you did. Your strategy is the culmination of all your decisions and how effectively you can align them with a particular end goal. Not to say that nothing significant happens, because it does, but for the most part you're playing from a macroeconomic perspective. This also frustrates some players because it can be hard to tell whether you are doing well, and there are so many choices to make without any clear indicator of what your priorities should be. It also doesn't help that the AI can be pretty brutal at times, so right when you are feeling way out of your element, someone is going to come along and crush you very unceremoniously, leaving you feeling pretty sour. I assure you that after a few shards, you will know what you are doing, and why you got crushed, and all that confusion and frustration will turn into excitement and possibilities.Heroes and troops are the core of shard conquering, and the best ones require a robust economy to support. Heroes engage in combat just like troops. They also can become very formidable relatively quickly, making lower level troops more like obstacles in a battle between heroes. There are 5 ranks of troops, and it takes a lot of time and resources to obtain higher ranks. Consequently, the combat effectiveness between the ranks is very significant. A dragon, hydra, or phoenix would be a rank 5 unit. These are very powerful, and could easily clean up an entire army low rank troops like swordsmen or clerics. This huge disparity of power is another frequent complaint. Just know that while each troop will have his moment of glory, and play a pivotal role in your advancement, most of them are unlikely to be useful beyond that point in the shard.The game has a ton of content. After 300 hours, I don't even have half of the achievements, and I'm constantly finding things I've never seen before. In combination with the stunning amount of replay value, this makes for a game that manages to stay fresh.My only complaints are AI turn times in large maps with many opponents during the late game can be long. Patches have made it better, but it's still irritating sometimes.It's had a history of bugs. The last patch introduced a pointer error that made it unplayable for me, but a reinstall seems to have alleviated it completely.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Eador is a fantasy strategy game with a lot of depth and enormous amount of playtime value.  The gameplay takes place on three levels: The campaign level, where you interact with the NPC overlords and decide which shard to attack and annex; the strategic level, where you explore and develop your provinces, and maneuver your armies; and the tactical, where your army faces off against another force in battle.  All three offer interesting choices and potential paths.  For instance, most of the decisions you make in the campaign level revolve around prioritising which shard to attack and conquer next.  Each one will unlock new tech and potentially offer other benefits; some are going to be harder than others terrain-wise; and of course as you encounter NPC overlords on the campaign level, they will also be attacking shards, potentially denying you tech when you want it. The strategic level-game reminded me of old-school AD&D at high levels, where players are ruling and developing territory, also of the old Heroes of Might & Magic games from 3DO.  Comparisons to HOMM3's gameplay are obvious, so I'll say that I think this is an excellent spiritual successor; for comparison, better than the later non-3DO HOMM games.The province exploration and dungeon-clearing are great fun; I especially like the sense of vastness each shard gets from the fact that every province can be explored, revealing dungeons, shops, or other locations.  On the tactical level, I also like the system where every individual unit has an XP track and gains levels, allowing for a lot of variation in strength and capability within a single unit type.  The downside to this is that a lot of tactical gameplay necessarily revolves around preserving your units so they can attain high levels; sacrificial gambits generally only make sense in a final push for shard victory.  That being said, the tactical combat is a lot of fun and definitely a worthwhile part of gameplay.My only larger criticism is that the campaign tends to get a bit repetitive, espeially in the early turns when you haven't conquered many shards and so have little tech to work with: invade a shard, defeat the local lords, annex, repeat from scratch.  But if those turns are formulaic, it's a GOOD formula, and more variation is added as you unlock more unit types to work with, to the repetition reduces over time.Highly recommended for any fan of fantasy strategy, particularly for fans of Heroes of Might & Magic or Avalon Hill's Titan.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I really wanted to love this game, and for the first 100 hours or so, I did. The problem I started to find was that the game was just a little too grindy. After the shine of a new concept, the novelty of the gameplay, and the fascination of the storyline wore off, I realized that I was really just playing the same battle over and over and over again. I tried to create a guide to help people with what to expect from the quest, and locations that you encounter, but it became such an undertaking that I had to tap out. If I had been enjoying the game, I would have kept going. It was during the creation of the guide that I realized that the combat map was the problem. You just use the same strategy over and over, as your play style preference doesn't give you a lot of options. All that said, I did get a ton of enjoyment out of the game. It was well worth the money I spent. I just wish that the game had more to offer, and didn't feel so much like doing the same thing over and over. I do recommend the game, and I hope you get at least a hundred hours out of it, at least. I can see myself playing this one again, because there is a lot of fun in it.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												This game has become a solid entry into the "4x" genre at this point. You conquer the Eador world shard by shard. Each shard you conquer allows you to build a little bit better buildings.  The combat is turn based and is done very well. The variety of monsters, creatures you will face is also very nice. I am a little over 16 hours into the game and I am on my 4th shard and to be honest it is getting a bit repetetive at this point. There is no hero carry over from shard to shard so after you conquer a shard you then recruit a new hero for the next. I think this is where the game falls a bit. You spend hours working through a shard, building your main provicence and adding a couple of smaller buildings to the conquered provinces all the while leveling up your hero. This is honestly quite a bit of work and takes grinding to beat the shard. However once you beat the shard , you lose all your progress and your hero. You essentially start the next shard at ground zero. Albeit you have access to a little bit better buildings but you do the same thing again. Start your hero at 0 and work on beating that shard. This is a fun game and at this point of its life plays solid- however I do not see myself logging 60 hours due to the repeat process on each shard. Things I think would make this game more enjoyable for longer play:Carry over your hero and make the next shard a level harder. This way you feel you are building towards something as you play through. Right now on shard 4 I stopped because I have a level 0 Warrior and he just croaked on 3 imps with 4 barbarians with him. It is frustrating considering on shard 3 I grinded my Mage to a great level and was enjoying the game. Then .... he is gone once the shard is defeated.Reduce the amount of searching in each province. To get to 100% per province takes quite a bit of time and is very repetetive. I find myself at this point in the game rolling my eyes when I hit nothing encountered 3x in a row and it becomes a click fest to see what you will find.Add more heroes if you plan on keeping the new hero per shard. They are quite generic and there is no real customization you can do to make the new hero on the next shard feel different. Right now you only have 4 to choose. I have already used all 4 and I am on my 4th shard. From what I read this game can reach 20+ shards per playthrough.The good :Pretty game. Graphics are solid.Combat is quite fun. I do like the movement points and I do like the challenge as the fights are not easy.The variety of monsters,creatures encountered is very large. Once you get the hang of city building with the wheel its pretty slick. I found myself realy enjoying the building aspect.All in all .. this a solid 4x entry ....however if you are like me and enjoy customization of your characters and buidling your characters over the course of the game you will find this quite repetetive and almost a chore when you hit the next shard. (notice my frequest use of the word repetetive)I would give it 7/10 based on solid gameplay, graphics,combat but it falls a bit due to lack of hero diversity, growth, and customization.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												An amazing Hex Based strategy game. It feels like an interesting mix of an RPG with hero units and tactical units, and this idea that there is this much larger struggle that you cannot intitally see. The game world looks great for what it is, and the enemies and units are all varied and well thought out. The game runs smoothly, the flow and pace of the game keeps you moving forwards without to much pause. The difficulty settings can keep even the most hardcore gamers entertained, providing a true challenge for those who think they can simply stomp through the game at their leisure. This game gives you so many ways to play it, and every way you can play it feels satisfying as hell.It's one of those games you literally have to pick up to experience it, as it can't truly be full explained. One of those mixxed bags of  a psuedo 4x strategy, but not quite that deep, with elements of other games like Heroes of Might and Magic, among older games from the early PC floppy days and Amiga era.If you like a more straight forwards approach to a psuedo 4x strategy game this would be it. They line it up and simplify it nicely, but keep all the complicated bits in if you want to play around with them and dig deeper. It's a must have for anyone that likes hero style tactics roleplaying gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												I originally bought the first Eador game - Genesis. This is basically a remake with improved graphics. And with this I am perfectly okay because the graphics were the only thing that needed some correction - the rest is perfectly awesome as it is. An Age of Wonders / HoMM sort-of-clone, Eador uses the very cool concept of you being a God conquering the 'shards' that make up the world to send you in multiple mission on relatively small maps as you try to make your way towards total domination. The game is a mix of strategy with some resource management (very basic stuff, really), RPG with growing heroes, items, and spells, and tactical turn-based battles on hexagonal grids, in the best Warhammer tradition. If you like this genre, it's good fun - and in this version, it now is good fun with very awesome looks.

content:
Posted: April 11
												This is a hidden gem. After the patch few weeks ago I'm back to this game and it sucked all my free time, even the one I don't have it (meaning nights without sleep). Don't get discouraged with minor bugs, this game is very deep fantasy turn-based strategy. I've bought this on sale in local "Ladybug" supermarket, and this was my first game on Steam, and thanks to it I discovered the whole Steam world. My journey with the game was a bit rocky, as at the beginning I ware really astonished by this game (that was like 3 years ago). I'm a turn-based strategy fun and I've played all earlier HoM&M games so I fell like in home. This game is  much different to the HoM&M series, but that is an advantage in this game and the climate is here. The most strong parts of this game is randomness and slow developing, and no this doesn't turn to frustration or boredom, it makes you want to discover. At first glace small shards seems simple, but once you'll be in game and you are an explorer like me, the single shard may take you weeks to conquer. The troops and hero choices seems rather small at first, but again after a while you'll see complex of development of them. And with other lords starting a war at random times and events that could eat your resources in one turn (of course it can double them as well) this keeps you busy. The game protects itself as some events have the good choice "moving", it means that for example that poisoning monsters may be a good idea at some time, but sometimes you'll accidentally poison your city, and there are far more things like that. Also the game "locks" a couple of turns so saving/load usually will not auto-solve problems. There is an "astral plane" where you decide which shard you'll take and also this is the place where story progress, I really like that point. I said that was a rocky road, as after few months of excitement (btw. since people are pointing this out,I'm playing in offline mode, currently I'm trying to keep my achievements up-to-date as proof) I got to the larger shard. When I ware slowly closing to the end the game started crushing. I tried to load earlier saves, do different things but the game ware still crushing. I've send save games, contact forums and producer but with no avail. With every patch I started the game to end in disappointment, till few weeks ago, now everything works fine, there are some errors in translations and so on, but since the producer is having now a hard time (see news section) I doubt those small things will be ever fixed.Highly recommended with warning this game will probably heavily "eat" your free time.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												I honestly couldnt decide if I should recommend this or not. Eador is a game with a very interesting playstyle, that has some serious problems preventing it from being great. I decided to recommend it because, despite its flaws, I am pushing a three digit playtime and still enjoying it.Eador looks like a 4X game, but I would argue that it is not. Your real focus here is on advancing your heroes. EVERYTHING COMES DOWN TO YOUR HEROES. You advance your heroes by clearing dungeons located in your provinces, which you locate with a "province exploration" mechanic, that is essential to advancing your economy. You will make far more money clearing these dungeons than you will with your economy, and the latter is really only there to support a few garrisons and pay for your leaders upkeep, which rises steadily.You explore your provinces to find dungeons for your heroes. You expand your empire to get more provinces, so that you can find more dungeons for your heroes. You expand your economy to support bigger armies for your heroes. You upgrade your castle so that you can get bigger bonuses for your heroes. All of your tech advances are aimed at getting better spells, and better units, and better equipment... for your heroes. The goal of this game is to be the first the get a hero to level 30 and max out its arsenal, at which point it becomes more powerful than everything else in the game except for another maxed out hero. Once you do this, you march to the enemies castles, and start taking them out.I have enjoyed this game a lot, because there are very few others quite like it, and the constant leveling is emotionally satisfying in an odd way. But, there are some real flaws. You cannot see far outside of your borders, and you cannot explore any areas you do not own, so the world feels vey small and lonely. You only ever meet your rivals when your borders physically touch, and even then you have no clear way to guage their strength. The world map will remain mostly hidden by the fog of war until you have conquered it, and even then there is no point in seeing everything. Just get to 30, find the keeps, and take them down.The first few turns are nearly impossible to get right until you have really gotten the hang of things. This game snowballs INTENSLY... messing up on turn 5 basically means that you have lost the game, but it will take you 300 turns to find that out. Eador forces you to save scum. There is no scaling of starting zones to lvl 1 armies, and the RMG can place you in a beginning position where none of your surrounding zones are capturable. Depending on your difficulty settings, the first 40 turns or so could be the hardest of the entire game, as you struggle for even the least of progress.Matches take so long (even the smallest of maps take 15 hours sometimes), that you cannot afford to simply play it by ear, you have to commit to a match for awhile. The largest sized maps can take a week to complete, if you really want to clear everything. The campaign is a joke. I spent the first 80 hours of my playtime on it, and I only barely got to the point where I could start to unlock t2 buildings. Basically, each campaign match unlocks (or permanantly locks) a single building and maybe a unit too, and gives you some small boost to your starting set-up. Given how long matches take, I could only assume an estimated 500 hour playtime for the whole thing, as there are hundreds of buildings in total. Either that or it ends way before you get everything.Pick it up if you like heavy RPG elements, that seems like what this game is focused on. But, dont expect a true 4X experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												I have been into Strategy games for about a year and a half now, have it RTS or Hex-Based. I love Strategy games, I love the strategy, I love that you need to care and protect your army in som RTS's or Hex-Based Strategy games. But this one falls a bit short of both of those. I love this game, do not get me wrong. I only have three hours in this game but it is still a fantastic Hex-Based for what it is. After you get your armor and weapon set down, you need no strategy to win battles. When your troops die, you don't need to worry since you can get 6,000 gold in the first hour and a half so you can constantly buy more and more troops, and you constantly get Gems which is currency for mage troops or buildings. You can have buildings in your kingdom to hire new troops or entertain your city population, etc. This is fun nonetheless, but one major bug (which is common, but not at all an annoyance) is the zero HP bug. Sometimes when an enemy reaches zero HP, they are still alive and you need to auto-attack in order to complete the battle. Other than that bug and the simplicity then comes into play with no strategy, if I had to rate this game, I'd give it a 7.5/10. If you would like to, check my FaceBook page, Gaming Reviews, for more reviews of many games! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Gaming-Reviews/496509297065566

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Eador is the first strategy game I've really been able to sink my teeth into. And that's saying something, because I seem like the kind of person to enjoy strategy games...The reason for this is because the game remains paletable throughout. I think the thing that typically drives me away from strategy games a few hours in is that, once you start to amass resources and turn those resources into troops, etc., there's so much to take care of at any one time that it's too easy to lose track of anything or everything.Eador isn't like that. While you can eventually get a gigantic army, colossal empire, and a mountain of resources, the buildup to that is very slow and easy to take in. Your armies are led by heroes, which cost exponentially more for each successive one, and each hero only starts with the capacity to have three units in its army (except for one, which starts with four slots). Over time, they'll level up and be able to lead more troops.Essentially, this leads to a strategy game where the most important resource is time. Hard limits are set on just how much you can do in a single turn, so, rather than a game where the first guy to get a billion troops wins, you get a game where the guy to best optimize his time wins.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2013
												This game, along with Eador: Genesis are a pair of turn based fantasy strategy games made by a handful of russian Devs, and it's cleary a labor of love. If you've played any classic fantasy strategy games like Heroes of Might and Magic, Disciples, or Age of Wonders, you'll feel right at home here. There's a large number of buildings to construct, units to field, all set over a massive, randomly generated campaign that gets more complex as you get further in. If you love any of the games I mentioned, this ones worth a look. One warning though: They're hard, especially Eador: Genesis, which forces you to play in ironman mode: no loading older saves when things go wrong.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Imagine a HoMM game that is more deep than its predecessor, but made by a small dev that cares. A game in which you really need to watch over your provinces. Many different things (presented as stories with few choices) may happen. Those can either boost or hamper your chances of winning. There are also many possibilities when it comes to building types. Every province is like a small city and choosing the right buildings to build there may affect your income, population, events and happiness. Other than the gameplay I also find the story better than typical heroic fantasy boredom.On the negative side (to some gamers) there is a lot of learning to be done and I recommend reading a basic guide. The one in the game does not cover some of the more complex features.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Similiar to Warlocks, Fallen Enchantress and good old Master of Magic, Eador is all about battling in a fantasy worlds with heroes and armies. While you spread your influence for gathering resources you shouldn't think you're the only one doing the same.As it is quite typical 4X game, there are few things that makes it work quite well - if you are about to invest some time to learn the game mechanics. That's the only drawback: construction (i.e. building up land) is more complicated, because you have capital region and "provinces" - and they don't develop the same way. Once you have built up buildings in your capital region you unlock more buildings for regions. And you can have only 3 buildings up on any given province, which doesn't make sense, but it forces you to prioritise. Luckily, you can tear buildings down on provinces. I wish there was a way to do the same on capital region, because you can have only 4 types of unit recruitment buildings.That restriction is horrible. At the beginning you need some first tier "barracks" in order to muster up your initial army to get you going anywhere. The beginning is quite rough even on lower difficulties. However, on later stages you wish you could have more variety of higher-end troops, but the cap limit won't allow you to do just that. What's even more painful, some "garrison" troops, which are different from standard troops, require also certain "barracks"-types, so you need to do some research. Later on, you get hold on that, though.Tactical battles are like from Fallen Enchantress. They can be very hard at first, but when taking full advantage of the terrain and vegetation it is possible. I am finding the very beginning quite hard on 2nd lowest difficulty level, though I haven't played but a couple of campaign maps. Like in Fallen Enchantress, you equip your hero, while troops get automatically geared up. Both heroes and troops gain levels and when they do, you can choose an upgrade for the victorious one. And when the leader gets level-ups, you can occasionally have more unlocked slots for more troops.Balance on economics work quite well. Gold is scarce, but if you do spare provinces' guards you are asking for trouble. On frontiers they won't save you much against enemy troops, but fortification gives you more time to get in aid with your armies. But these fortresses cost dearly. But you still need guards and pay for their upkeep, because there are plenty of events you get randomly attacked on one of your provinces. These events vary though, and some are helpful. However, the events can occur a lot. It isn't unprecendented to have got four events on your regions at the beginning of your turn.Graphics and sounds are okayish - nothing too brilliant, but they do their job.Definitely worth picking-up on your game library if you're into Master of Magic and/or Fallen Enchantress - especially on this summer sale. 75 per cent off is not too shabby.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Deep strategy, chess like gameplay, takes ages to get to grips with but very rewarding once you do.If your looking for a flashy game with great animations and personal custamization then... go find another 4x game because this isn't it.it's all about strategy, it's all about perfecting your early game and reaping the steam rolling rewards in the late game. It's on the deeper end of the complexity scale but unlike something like crusader kings 2, it's not initially mind boggling... for the most part. Though the building tree is extremely expansive and not very well laid out...It doesn't run very smoothly either... I've got a 780 now and it works fine, but my previous 570m on my l;aptop had some stuttering, though anything over a 760 should be very smooth. And most people have that at least, so this is just a wasted sentence i guess lol.anyway.the game has it's flaws; the campaign is excessivley long and boring. Though the writing is great I'd reccomend just free play or whatever it's called.also steam rolling... not very fun late game, it's a problem with most 4x games, it's steam rolling. Once you've bumped off the enemy commander a couple times YOU WIN.though it can be fun to maintain and manage a huge kingdom, exploring your lands etc. it's worth the price, it's worth putting a good 100-150 hours into, and it's a 4x game I'll be coming back to at some point. The ai is very good and it's heart warming to see how many different strategies can be played out in this game.

Here's hoping it helps.Until the stability is addressed, I would not recommend people buy it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												A good game with very original ideas. The idea of the shards is really nice and you get new buildings and new troops every shard. Many strategies are possible during each shard and you may wanna try every kind of heroes. The story of the campain is rather original well written and nicely thought, with opponents who all have their own secrets about how they became high spirits. Also, it is rather original and pretty nice to feel like you are a high spirit immortal and fighting for shards that look like little planets in the stars. Another positive point with the idea of the shards is that you can have several strategies on them : you can rush it, you can take your time exploring every region, trying to find btw legendary weapons or extra bonuses for winning the shard. On the other hand, it is true there are bugs in this game. However, in my games, I never had any bug that warned me from playing the game (always had minor bugs that didnt affect the game). Another negative point is that you cant have bonuses for your heroes when you get a shard. You always have to do the same farming for your heroes and it is kinda repetitive.But still I strongly recommend this game .

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												I am actually glad that I decided to go through with this game despite the bad reviews that users have been giving it. At a glance, it looks a lot like most fantasy setting 4x hexagonal grid strat rpg games, but this one is by far more punishing. As an example, the Age of Wonders series, when you make a mistake in that game it is typically a simple process to work your way back out of it, time consuming, but simple. This game is a lot less forgiving, to the point that even with all the right moves, you downright have to be cheating to get anywhere at all. In one game I had a single hero at level 2, was barely managing to stay on top of 4 hexes of land, and then a SINGLE beginner difficulty AI warrior hero comes along and stomps me. in the same amount of time the AI had somehow magically managed to have a level 5 hero, with 2 maxed abilities, and another with three points in it, which as far as I know so far, is not evne possible. So, all in all I definitely would have to give this game a 7/10, just for the sake of the mind-numbingly stupid situations I find myself in because of the balancing.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Eador: MotBW if a solid game for sure. Gorgeous art, simple and yet fairly dynamic balanced mechanics, original aesthetic. Nothing not to like from this small time developer. Also, they are updating and adding to the game all the time.However, the tutorial does drag on too much, and by the time you can build a full realm (all tiers unlocked) it kinda feels like you've already played the game for what it's worth. The story here is original, but there isn't much to keep you hooked. Add to that buggy coop/multiplayer and after 40 or so hours, I put this on back on the proverbial shelf.If your really like 4x RPG's, don't miss this one!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2013
												Eador shipped out with plenty of bugs and very little new content compared to the other Eador game... In fact it was just graphics and some campaign mechanics that were updated... So... for a turn based strategy/RPG for 20bucks that comes out of the soviet union, this is pretty good. The problem is I spent 40 hours on genesis, and since this is identical, it bores me much quicker than it should... Overall, if you are a fan of these turn based strategy games, this is a steal for the price it has on... Comparable to Fallen Enchantress, but way cheaper...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												The best way to describe Eador: Master of the Broken World is that is very much like heroes of might and magic or other hex based, turn based combat games mixed with a strategic map more alike something from the total war series.But unlike other games set in alike setting, you do not get to chose race, however in its place is a karma system and so you still deal with creatures of different alignments and it also extends to the strategic events and affects such things as random events.There are a few problems, namely the random nature of events and not knowing what causes it. I felt that it took a good while before things became clear to the players as to what might trigger within certain terrain, by certain races and for what reasons. While some might argue that it keeps things fresh and you on your toes at all times, I found it at least as much frustrating to be punished for things I couldn't possibly predict.Because of this, some other random elements and because of limited knowledge of unit composition and generally what a good way is to start, I would say this game has a very steep learning curve. For some this might be a strictly bad thing, while others might enjoy figuring things out.It should also be said that the more you learn, the more restricted you might feel as some choices are real not much of a choice at all, like your starting hero for example.Sometimes the games can drag on, and because the game is repetitive in its nature, due to how the campaign is played by generating a new map with a basic start for every single new world you try to take over, progression can feel slow and unrewarding between maps.But overall, it can be very tactically challenging and worthy the time of those who enjoy some management and above all this style of hex based turn based combat.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Awesome game that so far keeps me coming back for more. Its one of those games where I keep thinking..."Just one more turn, then I'll go to bed". Choose from 4 classes for your first hero/general and then build up armies to follow him around capturing provinces and hunting for treasure as you go. As your resources grow, recruit more heros to lead other armies. Its got a bit of everything - loot, RPG character progression, a story (which I havent really kept up with as I'm fairly early in),  exploration, base building and army customisation.For people that remember games like Gladius, this is about as close as it gets but with more frills. Highly recommended and was a complete steal in the flash sale. My only gripe is that completing some of the quests for the foreign races that you encounter in order to make them allies are sometimes near impossible to complete. Some more directions in game as to where to go to complete the quest would be good, instead of just "Find this item" (which could be anywhere amongst the dozens of map hexes, and in turn anywhere within the hex!).I had originally got Heroes of Might and Magic which was also on sale, but this is so far infinitely better in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Eador: Masters of the Broken World is an enjoyable game inspired by the Heroes of Might and Magic series and the King's Bounty series.  However it does stumble a bit initially.  Players who don't fully understand the game are likely to stumble at the start of games after the tutorial if they play on difficulties other than the easiest.  This is compounded by the tutorial not doing a good job of explaining how to start each match and the game forgetting to tell players some of the ways of earning experience, like exploring.  The best way to learn this game is to approach it like something out of the 90's and go read the manual.  You should also make sure to turn up the battle speed significantly to make sure that it doesn't have horrible pacing in fights.  Eador also has bugs that range from minor nuisances to crashes that force you to restart your computer.  For me, Eador froze twice in my first four hours of gameplay and made my computer lock up twice more by the time I hit twenty hours.  Assuming they are willing to risk the bugs in this game, people who enjoyed the Heroes of Might and Magic series, the King's Bounty series, or other similar games will enjoy Eador also although it generally implements each element of its gameplay in a more average manner than another similar game although it balances this out by having more elements to its gameplay than other similar games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Pros:- Lengthy campaign- Well designed and flexible turn-based combat system- Random event/world generation- Overflowing with elements from other genres to add depth- Multiple playstyles can be effective- Well implemented auto-save systemCons:- Campaign is a bit too lengthy due to repetition- Still riddled with bugs that can be game breakers- No voice audio, entirely text-driven plot- Erratic AI behaviour and levellingUltimately if you are a fan of the turn-based strategy genre then you probably won’t want to miss out. But until Snowbird either adds in a whole new raft of features (multiplayer options, alternate ways to conquer shards) then for the sake of pretty graphics it’s hard to imagine why you would pay upwards of £20 for an identical remake of a game that is still available for £2 - especially in a genre where graphics are less than a secondary concern.  The amount of bugs and crashes I experienced as well as the constant repetitiveness makes this a hard game to recommend but at the same time I have enjoyed the game and how exceptionally well this game is put together beneath the surface.  Juggling multiple management systems and tieing them to karma, story and making the whole experience fluid is not something to dismiss on a whim, however that already appeared to be present in the original game, so the question remains: what value has Snowbird Games really brought to Eador?  That is a question I struggle to answer, even after 98 hours.A (now) solid turn based strategy game that stands shoulder to shoulder with many others but perhaps not quite matching the immersion that the Heroes of Might and Magic series provided.  What it lacks in story and frills it more than makes up for with in depth mechanics and gameplay however it is difficult to see anyone who is pressed for time or ambivalent about this genre sticking with Eador beyond the first few hours - especially when the tutorial alone took me 6 hours because I hadn’t realised there was no need to explore everywhere to 100%!  It’s a shame as the game really comes alive after the first few hours of invading a shard when you get the tier 3 and 4 creatures involved to take on the larger encounters in the game.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												A most excellent game. Eador starts out slowly, and has a tutorial that may frusterate a long time TBS game player, but once it hits its stride you start to feel like the God of a New World (death note quote 0.0) The game plays in a similar manner to Age of Wonders, with heroes and units doing turn based battles, but sets itself apart with its Province and shard systems. A shard is one of the pieces of the titular broken world, which when conquered joins itself to your fledgling domain and give you advantages to use in further conquest. Each shard is made up of a number of provinces, each with its own denizens, dungeons, and enemies. The meat of the game lies in the empire building aspect. Your heroes will spend a lot of time exploring the frontiers of you empire, pushing back the wilderness and revealing lost ruins, dens of evil, and the occasional friendly group. Quests and events will come every now and then, leaving you to decide how you want to rule your empire. The focus can lead to a forgetable shard endgame, as in my experience by the time the AI lords began to move against me I had heroes who could singlehandadly slaughter their armies, but I have only done one Shard so far. There does appear to be a diplomacy function, both on the shard and greater level, as well as a greater threat against the universe in a nebulous chaos, but I haven't gotten there yet. TL:DR Great fantasy TBS Game, lots of depth, some balance issues. 8/10

content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												I give it a 6.  I got about 15 hours out of it before I got bored.  It's a great concept and very ambitious.  The game gets bogged down in tedious combat, unbalanced units, and dumb AI.  Normal units require too much baby sitting to really level, but that's okay because high level heros dominate the field single-handed.  The strategic game lacks too: You're too busy conquering new areas (or re-conquering) to really explore or do quests except as side effect.  The meta-strategic is also neat, but you're so rarely there that it's more an aside than core gameplay.Really, I enjoyed what they were trying to do here, but I'd rather go play something a little more complex, such as Elven Legacy.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												The game play itself is addicting and even beyond the "take over the world" goal, you can set up a huge number of secondary goals. Certain locations will give you tasks to complete for rewards, you can aim to complete item sets for your character, aim to fully explore all of your territory (that takes awhile, by the way) and much more.The campaign is structured in a way that each map you win gives you access to a few additional structures when playing the next map.  However, you do start over from scratch on each map.  I enjoy the restart from scratch part of the game, but if that's not your thing, you might find that aspect of the game frustrating.I have not encountered any of the game breaking bugs that are out there, and hopefully the most recent patch has resolved them.  Maybe I'm just lucky, maybe the developers have been able to get most of them fixed.  Either way, I fully recommend this game for the hours of entertainment in can provide.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												MotBW, at it's heart, is a very good game. The mechanics are solid, the art is great, and the replayability is high. However, the game suffers from very poor balance and many, many bugs, some of which can be game-breaking. The developers seem to be keeping on this, and have recently released several patches that address some of the major flaws. I would hope that they continue to focus on this aspect (bugfixing) before moving on to others, such as any expansions that have been rumored. Overall this is very enjoyable 4X game, despite the aforementioned bugs. I do reccomend it to people with the patience to watch a fairly 'ok' game evolve into a great one, hopefully.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Eador is a really good game. It has an interesting world, great tactical combat (on par with Fantasy General), a lot of choice in developing your heroes and kingdom. I could go on about what's great about it... yet, I am giving it a negative recommendation. It is because at the same time it is a really badly written game, it has been plagued by bugs since day one. The devs have released a lot of patches, fixing many things and adding interesting features... but also adding new crashes and when the last patch broke game saving I decided that I can't believe in this game any more. If in some distant future they manage to fix all the bugs this will be a great game. But with every single patch breaking more things than it fixes I really can't believe in that.EDIT> After the last patch it is playable for me... there are bugs still, but ATM nothing game breaking. So I'm giving the game a positive recommendation.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2013
												**WARNING** - This is NOT for those of you that want to mindlessly click and play and have instant gratification for little or no work. Go play Great Big War Game for that. This game simply put is the best Turn Based Strategy title to come down the pike since Civ 5. It is hard, yes. Even on easy it is difficult to manage and balance all the things you need to manage and balance in these type games (Economy, happiness, army upkeep etc). There IS a way to accomplish it but it takes smarts and determination. The rewards are well worth he work. The Pros and Cons are as follows :PROS :1.) Easy to learn interface. If you cant master this interface in the first 10 minutes then you need to exit the game and delete it because you will be lost like a fart in a whirlwind. Go play solitare as it is more your speed.2.) Tutorial brings you up to speed. Easy to learn, hard to master 3.) Very challenging. This is not a simple fast gratification game. Hard core TBS gamers only.4.) The Risk vs Reward system is well balanced unlike other games. 5.) A Deep, rich game that has untold hours of replayability in it.Cons :1.) Poorly designed building tech tree. It has some good elements to it BUT the design of it makes it very difficult to know what to build to get the unit, spells, items you want. Could have been much better.2.) The AI tends to take too long in making its moves on the overall map and in combat .... but at least in combat you can move your combat speed to max and that fixes the problem.3.) The game sometimes will hang in combat and get stuck in the hourglass mode ... but you can hit ESC and then click "Quick Combat" and it will simulate the results for you ending the battle. They should patch that problem soon I hope. Well that about sums it up. If you are a hardcore TBS gamer ... this is for you .... if you are a casual TBS gamer ... move along .... back to RISK for you :)

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												If you're a fan of turn based hexagones tactical battles this is a must have.I came in hoping a game like Heroes of Might and Magic, but I really got surprised with the tools, storyline and options you're able to explore.This game will bring you to a medieval world full of disputes for power and glory; different races trying to survive and expand their lands, wealth and people.Besides that, you're not a mere mortal king or lord, but you're above them all, trying to reach a higher purpose - which you will be able to chose through your fate and will.Conquering world pieces to build your own or eliminating all lives around, you can do whatever you want in your path.So I basically recommend this game because:- Really awesome tactical turn based battles with unique features and options, which you need to explore all resources and be a strategist (depending on game difficulty);- Interesting concepts evolving into a storyline which you can mold a world depeding on your alingment and convenience, which makes a nice roleplaying;- Interesting 3D character models (action) and pictures (events) mix;- Very explicative tutorial that accompanies you throughout the game, appearing when given situation occurs;- Freedom.Things I consider negative, but I hope they'll fix in future patches, mostly bugs:- Crashes when specific situations occur (casting a particular spell or something like that);- Game forum with restrictions and difficulties in accessing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												If you enjoy the old school Heroes of Might and Magic you'll like this game. It takes out some of the more frustrating resource management by reducing the types of resources from 6 to 2. Heroes feel a little underpowered in this game, but the four classes are pretty well balanced. The campaign mode adds a nice level of strategy. While each shard you conquer feels like its own world, and is a brief heroes of Might and Magic style game unto itself, the strategic brilliance is in how they link each conquest. As you conquer shards you obtain benefits and unlock technology that you can use in later conquests...for a price. The writing could use some polish, and it's difficult to pin down exactly, but it feels at times as though maybe a less than thorough job was done translating the game from another language. The real gold of this game is in its expanse. It is basically impossible to completely explore every shard, or at least would take a very long time, and the game does a nice job of providing you with new and different encounters. Do I want to try and forge an alliance with the elves on this shard or the halflings? Is it worth the time or should I just slaughter them all and take their lands? Should my hero spend his time hunting down that dragon that's plagueing my kingdom or should he pillage my enemy's domain? It's also nice to be confronted with actually insurmountable obstacles from time to time. No I can't explore this laborynth and kill it's minotaur at level one, but just because I can't face it, doesn't mean I can't see it. So many games have the "you'll get there when you're ready" mentality and it negatively affects suspension of disbelief. The story is fairly generic fantasy, but Astral politics can be fun, and it's nice that the way you treat your subjects and those around you has a concrete effect on the way they interact with you. That being said, being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ isn't all bad like it is in some games. Some races respect bloodthirst and power. As a do-gooder, I constantly had my orc provinces in rebellion because they view me as oppressive and weak. Certain Astral entities will ally with you out of fear or respect for power rather than just sycophantic loyalty to kindness.All in all I very much enjoy this game. Is it Shakespeare? No, but it certainly passes the time.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Really love this game. Not too difficult and not too easy, just right. This is a TBS type of game. The world consists of shards, which you have to conquer. Every shard consist of a number of provinces. Your hero (as usual you can have a number of them) has to conquer the provinces. Once a province is conquered you can explore it (find treasure, etc. usually leading to a fight or negotiation) pleasing the local population make money from them build mining facilities, mills etc. There are many kind of buildings to build and paths to choose. In between, events take place that you must resolve in some way. For instance there is some wizard that resurrects some death people and you have to decide whether to fight the wizard, pay it off or ignore it (just making this one up as an example).Fights bring you to a hexagonal field which is pretty much standard across TBS type of games and you have to fight the enemy with the army you have (pretty much like you have it in other TBS games like king's bounty).Loads of fun and highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												I played this a lot, there are many good ideas, the game is very interesting and addictive.However I will not recomend this. There are quite a lot of game breaking bugs. For example if the oposing units have the "atack and move"traints, they will simply  exterminate your army. This is an easy bug to find and fix, I found this in my game 6 months ago, and is still there . And there are other bugs:Your hero will randomly get stuck while moving from province to province, or it will automaticly fight an invisible army and die. This kills your hero, you need to load a previos save and after 10-20  times you simply have enoght. This game has many good ideeas, I like the mecanichs but with all this bugs ( and no fixing in sight), I can not recomend it.Edit. After a long time, finally the developer release a patch for many bugs, including the ones I mention above. Plus as a apology for the extremly long time, they release a free DLC. After playing for 7 hours I did not found any major bugs.The game is not perfect, it has some balancing issues, but it is addictive and quite interesting.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												I've played Eador for some hours and nearly two days non-stop. It is a promising game, really a masterpiece of a crossover between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic, the battles are really difficult but still fair, with the exception of 1-2 enemy units. It is a lot of fun for ppl who like to manage a lot, but still enjoy a nice battle every now and then.The main flaw why I wouldnt recommend this game is, because on the technical side it's a mess. Errors prompting up every 5-30 minutes, most of them just stop the game from running, the minimum specs are a lie and the loading times are unbelievably long. You could say that in a playtime of 8hours you effectively have played 3-4.Still I would recommend Eador for being one of those games that really fascinate you, if you give it the chance and maybe have a good PC, the game is still a work in progress so maybe it will get better in time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												(This review is from my opinion and has doesn't cover any issues the game others claim it may have.)Well worth the money and time invested. It's a game that keeps you coming back so long as you're not a casual player. Has the hardest campaign I've ever played by far and I'm still playing on beginner without finishing or starting a new campaign for the whole time I've actually spent playing the game (over 190hrs). But it's been time well spent. The style of the artwork, the units, the models, the abilities and depth just work sooo well together.  I ACTUALLY feel like I'm in control of a kingdom while I'm playing. My choices have meaning and consequence/benefits. Although thats obvious when you play some games. I feel if I had to choose between games like ROME total war, Age of wonders series, Civ 5 etc, all those turn-based conquest stratagy games, I'd rather uninstall the rest than stop playing this one. But thats just my opinion.The game in full could be taken furthur if the developers spent the same amount of time they spent making the game to make it go ever furthur. More intereactions, more interesting situations your kingdom might face, THINGS like shards clashing in the middle of conquering one shard then 2 more enemy kingdoms rock up that were originally clashing on that shard to begin with now I have to conquer both with more mayhem to add to the mix. The forging of alliances out of shards with other demi-gods, THE LIST is endless.For what it is though it's amazing and a true inspiration towards what fantasy games should be/feel/look like. Not to mention the idea of shards and it's turn based stratagy while conquering territories. Well done! ^_^p.s to myself: This review after reading does not serve the game justice, I feel its more than what I described by far but I couldn't find the words :(

												Super complex if you mind exploiting undead/summons; but getting into the game is deceptively easy. Pulls you right in and then gives you challenges to meet your level of ability (or at least it does if you're paying attention). Only gripe is how long games must play out and how much of the game mechanics are not immediately obvious to players who want to learn organically and don't enjoy reading strategy guides. But the game is totally random after the first couple levels, so replay is still good. Very important because the same turn-based mechanics are played out over and over on the territory map.
