content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I had a hard time deciding wether to recommend this game or not given the current flaws it has.Watch a few youtube videos to understand the mechanics and know that this is game about trial and error. The battle prediction is broken, dont trust it ... there are some predicted "very easy" encounters which in my oppinion cant be won. A battle against 4 medusas without a ranged hero is a loss regardless of predictions.The above brings me to the next obvious point; inbalance. The devs simply did not take their time to implement this propperly, some creatures are simply too powerfull for early game and you have to know this prior to engaging ... unless you dont mind reloading a lot.Early positioning and ressources can also be an issue, but in my oppinion not as vital as the two flaws mentioned above.PS: None of the issues were ever fixed, combat prediction is herrendous and AI cheats. Changed from positive to negative due to that reason.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Incredibly deep 4x game. Steep learning curve and a bit buggy but still well worth the price of admission. Gameplay does get a bit repetitive but the sheer number of units, buildings and various strategies you can employ, in addition to the unique challenges presented by each shard ensures every shard skirmish feels unique from each other.It's so fun leveling up your heroes, buidling armies, developing provinces, learning magic, buying items, exploring, casting rituals, hiring guards, conquering provinces, adventuring...this game really scratches an itch. Not for the faint of heart or someone seeking a casual game but definitely a gamer's game. Only negative is it's a slow game and takes many, many hours to play....so enter if you dare!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												It's got a bit of a stiff learning curve and the tutorial is actually kind of weird / buggy. I'm a fan of Civ / Master of magic type games and that's what this is. Dozens of "shards" each being a unique world ruled by one or more local lords and possibly a higher being (similar to you). You can use diplomatic relations with the higher beings or just fight everything, be a kind rule and loved or a tyrant and feared. Take things be force and pillage or grow and build. Every shard you claim unlocks new spells, troops and items so it's motivation to go for the hard ones. All in all a really fun game with a good auto save, buggy at times but auto save bails you out and you really open it up / start to enjoy a couple shards in so stick with it / power past the tutorial and the 1st demo shard if you can and you'll be rewarded with a lovely game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I will update the review as I play more through the game.First thing: Eador: MoBW is hard, and immensely time consuming, if you are not a big fan of 4x and Turn-Based Strategy you'll hate this game, if you're not a fan of this genre already Eador will not transform you onto one. I have more than one hundred and twenty hours of gameplay and was only able to conquer ten shards, nevertheless know that to finish the game you need twenty five. This means approximately twelve hours per shard, therefore I am talking about three hundred hours of campaign. And I am only playing on the third hardest difficulty. I am sure that in the hardest one I would not be able to finish the game. This characteristic force you to use the best strategy you can think in order to do absolutely anything. Eador is a low-number-status game, so each single positive thing you can figure out will make a enormous difference, the same applies to negative ones. The terrain on the battle map is extremely important, the single "1+ defence" a hill give can make the difference between everything. Personally to me this is a positive point if I liked easy and casual things I would study art or some other meaningless area, not physics.There is one thing that almost kill this game, the sense of progression. But the Eador's developers are one the the best on Steam, and even after two years they are trying to fix this problem through patches. It worked on certain aspect but the problem persists. After each shard you conquer (after ten hours) you goes back to the astral plane and have to start every thing all over again, this creates the feel that all your effort was in vain. Now with the new patch you can transfer your hero and equipment to your next shard, so you can progressively construct your hero etc, creating the feeling that your efforts are really meaning something, that your efforts are constructing something. Nevertheless this costs astral energy, and every thing is so expensive that you will only be able to continue with your weakest and meaningless hero, probably the level 6 Commander that in the end of the shard's battle you create just for province exploration.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												The last time I extensively played Eador was back in summer of 2013, outside of Steam. The game was quite new. It had tons of bugs but it was mostly playable. However it was no secret it was unfinished and many important mechanics did not work. But the small team of developers really deserve a load of respect because now a year and dozends of patches later - after many fans may have given up their hope on Eador and even taunted the creators "Masters of the Broken Game" on their official support forums - the game is great. My comeback to the game today was worth and to honor the good work on the game the devs put into it I decided to buy it on Steam. I never thought they could recover this game and even more important giving the UI a needed refresh. By today the game is like it should have been at release - it is fun and can be challenging. There are still some drawbacks: it can be confusing to learn how to conquer the shards and how the whole works.The AI may be still better. The monsters, items and events you face on the shards are very repetitive. Not to start talking about the music.  Apart from that I would give Eador a good 6 of 10 rating. If you have some time kill and you love to combine strategy with roleplay elements  it is definitely worth the few bucks it costs! In strategic aspects how creatures are fighting each other it reminds me a bit of Magic the Gathering. Bad luck for Windows 8 users this game needs .NET Framework 3.5 to be installed to work properly.I rate the game with a 7/10.1 point less for the repetitive music and missions1 point less for the remaining bugs (mostly AI) and crashes1 point less for the fact you have to delete a preexisting profile and start a new campaign to unlock steam achievements, also to get access to the DLC. if you played Eador before you got it on Steam and like to play on like me, it will be troublesome.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												Was kinda leary about this title as the game story seemed a bit odd (shards of a world floating aimlessly in space?  Really?)  I recieved it in a 5 dollar bundle deal.  Playing through the tutorial seamed a bit clunky and glitchy, but that was just the tutorial.  After the first few days of playing (countless hours of playing) , wow, I really like this game.I will use an analogy from the game story to describe the game.  Its like a gem broken into pieces floating aimlessly, spend some time collecting and putting them together, well, its a gem to behold (thus far).Its not your typical pick a race, class, here are your abilities, now get to it game.  The shards you attempt to conquer, will add to your abilities and somewhat define and refiine your strategy.  The game has been a pleasant journey of discovery as it doesnt come with a manual (although you can find the manual through google translate if you need game info).  Shards of different gametypes, pieced together (ex: HoMM, Masters of Magic, Warlords, etc) and its friggen extensive.  I am over 40 hours in and not even halfway through.   Altogether, it works for me and if you like these kind of games, you should find this a unique experience as well.Did I mention the game is huge?  Some shard battles I take time to do some quest, others I have been forced to finish fast as the enemy gives me difficulties (I started playing on skilled mode).  I have heard complaint that the game gets redundant or repetative.  What game do you enjoy playing that doesnt get repetative?  The game solves this with some auto functionality.  You can just quickview the battle, or set it to auto and watch the battle play out.  Sometimes I am forced to do the manual battle as the AI doesnt do the strategy required to win.  It will say this should be easy then you lose your entire army.  The game does save every minute or so and I suggest you do some manual saves (just in case, as there is no restart scenario option).  In all its a minor annoyance in all the richness this game offers.I have seen many gripes on the forums concerning this game, I have none here.  I guess you will either love it or hate it, but dont be swayed buy the naysayer if the above mentioned gametypes gave you some joy back in the day.  Eador:  Master of the Broken World is a worthy game.Now if you will excuse me, I have some shards to conquer.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												I like it. It isn't perfect by any means, but I keep finding myself coming back for more.Combat could be a little more indepth, and character developement could be made more customized... But with 200 hours on record, I shouldn't be too picky ;)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A true indie gem that I highly recommend to all turn-based strategy fans, particurly those fond of Heroes of Might & Magic.This game really surprised me, with taking the essentials from Heroes of Might & Magic but then going their own way.  Eador features combat akin to HoMM, but with much better battle maps that feature actual terrain and interesting, if not simple, innate abilities of the different races.  Beyond the battles the game has an intriging take on territory control and expansion as you capture tile-based provinces with their own terrain features and special resources as well as associated choice-based random events with decent writing and fun outcomes.  Finally, the story and lore is actually quite interesting and kept me playing for a long time into the campaign.Ultimately the game suffers from a lack of unit variety (two subfactions - basically good and evil - plus a neutral third filled with different monsters) and thus battles and maps do eventually get monotonous.  But for an indie game, I was thoroughly pleased and could recommend this game to anyone expecting as much.

												First off, this isn't a BAD game, per se, it's just really......really....slow.I like TBS games, and I like RPG games, and this has elements of both.  Think Heroes of Might and Magic style battles but with more RPG elements.  But I can tell this is going to be a long game, with lots of story/text.  Right out of the gate there's a lot of talking and it pretty much put me to sleep.  I mean, yes it was the campaign with tutorial settings, but I found everything just moved too slowly for my liking compared to some other games.It's pretty basic, nothing really new to see at all, it's not horrible so I can't NOT recommend it, but don't expect it to blow your socks off.5.5/10

Posted: June 22, 2014
												The game has a large amount of rather interesting mechanics; for instance units gain new abilities as they level up and some of them change them dramatically (fairies get a dodge ability that makes it so being attacked by a higher level enemy makes them retreat unless they are cornered or out of stamina for instance). It is a pity that units are so relatively fragile you won't be seeing any of that most of the time. Heroes are relatively overpowered to everything so the game turns into leveling them up and dungeon crawling for money sidling the rest of the military and economic development that exists in game.Given the amount of bugs this game has, I doubt they'll be fixing that fundamental issue which turns the game into a boring slog to level up your hero and then smash your opponent.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												This is the turn based strategy game I have been trying to find for years.  The "mixed" reviews on Steam almost turned me away but I am glad it didnt.  I have had the game for less than two months, and am at 341 hours played as of this writing.  I still haven't beaten it.  If I had to quickly describe this game, I would say it is a perfect marriage of playstyles from Brigandine (a PS1 turn based SRPG) and Civilization.ProsInsanely addicting gameplay, with that "one more turn" craving.The balance of units and their usage is very appropriate.The story and writing are actually surprisingly good, and thats usually a non factor for me in a game focused on pure gameplay.  It's not an epic tale you'll be telling your friends about, but the individual characters are distinguishable and it's a rather neat premise.  Additionally, humor is intermingled in rather well.The gameplay has a "roguelike" feel to it, in that after every shard you conquer you move on to another shard and start off almost from scratch.  Over time you gain more and more benefits you can start the next shard with, but it is very much a fresh new start every time.  Personally for me, this is what keeps racking up the hours.  I would also like to give praise to the great attention to detail on units, and also the vast catalog of equippable items and buildings to employ.ConsOther reviews really only harp on two things, difficulty and bugs.  The bugs do exist, and the game does crash.  There is an autosave feature that saves the game every turn, which addresses this pretty well, but it is still annoying.  It is NOT a reason to give up on, or dismiss this game entirely.  The difficulty may be hard for people new to SRPGs.  For me, I updated the difficulty level to "Expert" not too far into the game, and I am not struggling on any one stage.  This concern is also well addressed because they have I think 8 options for difficulty and can be adjusted.  There is a learning curve with troop usage and all of the classes involved, but a huge variety of successful strategies to develop which truly makes this game interesting.DLCI recommend playing the game a bit first and making sure you dig it before buying.  You'll probably know pretty quickly.  If you do enjoy the game, the DLC is a welcome addition to it.SummationIf you are looking for a turn based SRPG that you can play for 10 minutes at a time or easily lose an entire weekend to it all the same, this is a solid choice.  This is the best SRPG I have been able to find since the PS1 era.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Gawd, I've never "turned" on a game this quickly. I played and enjoyed Eador Genesis. So when this came out I was excited. It's essentially the same game with much prettier graphics. It look great, the interface is better and I enjoyed it for a while. I really give them props on some of the art - it's some of the best out there. The quests can be fun and there's a great balance between enhancing your own territories and going after new ones. Then two problems hit me:1. It's repetitive. Very repetitive. You start on a shard, build up, conquer the enemy and start all over again from scratch on a different shard. Rinse and repeat. That's not very compelling gameplay. They would have done much better with a faster paced, more open gameplay style.  I could forgive that. After all, it's okay for a while. What I can't forgive is flaw #2.2. This "strategy" game is nothing of the sort for one reason - the AI cheats and will give it's side resources that are comparable to yours even if you should vastly outproduce them. So the whole game becomes an illusion because you aren't really "playing" the other side, you're playing against a bunch of foes that are generated directly in response to your own force. If you found a way to find a million gold in the game, rest assured the AI would have similar resources the next turn even if they were down to one or two territories left. As a result, the game is fundamentally broken in a way that will never be fixed. It's not a strategy game at that point because the AI doesn't need to play with any strategy. I figured this out when I saw the AI pushing units it could not possibly create with only one city left. After some exploration and some help unravling the back end, we found that's the way it works. So there is no real "AI". It's like playing Civilization if the AI could just give itself cities and armies out of thin air every turn. That ruined the game for me. Oh, it still has bugs and the gameplay is also still repetitive. But it's knowing how badly the AI can cheat that was the deal killer. It's lazy and insulting to the players. As such, Eador sadly gets two thumbs down from me.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Is the game worth it? Simply put yes - in a pure cost per hour it represents great value. But if you're looking for a flawless gem then this is not the game you're looking for, its greatest strengths are also its greatest weaknesses.By all means buy the game, enjoy it for what it is and appreciate the depth of control you have and perfecting your chosen methods/tactics. However this is rather like a marathon - you do it once, maybe you talk about doing it again but when you get back in training you realise the memory is better than the actual experience and there are better things to do with your time.When this game was first released the bugs made it torturous to play, despite its underlying appeal. The bug fixes and subsequent DLC addressed the vast majority of these and added some additional diversity into the game and the alliances you could build.The unit progression is superb, allowing you to tailor to your playstyle while still retaining a small element of randomness. It's gratifying to see your minions grow and develop, reaching landmark skills/abilities and being able to deploy them accordingly. It's less gratifying to see them die on turn one of a battle before you can act. The realism of this is appreciated however anything resembling an offensive spellcaster is going to spend its life cowering at the back being chain healed awaiting the arrow that will finally kill it. After carefully nurturing them to a level where they get decent spells this is not entertaining. To avoid this you are left with only a small selection of units to use (or you go with a hero that does all the work while the creatures in the army are more like cheerleaders). The other failing is the high level units you can build are ultimately not needed meaning every level is the same army; the game fails to challenge you to change your playstyle, the 'differences' between the worlds are not level defining and every shard is the same. While I don't always like the myriad of missions that are often forced on players in games such as these the totally directionless play isn't rewarding. And just when you think it is you win the level and start from scratch.My first playthrough was long, I inadvertently picked the longest win condition and proceeded to conquer every shard in turn. It was clear from the achievements there were a number of ways to win but none presented themselves. For me the replay value of a game is key, I love to go back and play games again in a different way, or using different tactics and this one is no different. Once I finished it I wanted to go back and play again; different heroes, different endings, different bonuses. The problem is after a shard or two I realised that I was going to be doing this for another 200 hours (and that there was no joy in trying to do it differently). While the longer I spend away from the game the more fondly I think of it a few hours playing it again drives me away.I don't regret buying it, or the time spent. Perfecting the tactics, overcoming the AI's tendency to cheat spectacularly, finally closing down a shard and managing the grumpy inhabitants of the cities was something I enjoyed at the time. But not something I want to do again and it's something many people won't want to do at once.

Posted: November 24, 2015
												I have so many complaints about this game, I'm not even sure where to start.  I love games like Kings Bounty, Age of Wonders, Civilization etc.  But Eador just sucks, just keep clicking in explore province over and over again get's so boring and repetitive I'll start playing games on my cell phone as well = / I've also found most of the time in the begining when your hero is underpowered, the notifications of how powerful the enemies you'll face is frustatingly inaccurate. This really took the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Just seeing, "this enemy is easy" and then going into battle and have all your units die in 3 turns, and then you have to wait for your hero to ressurect, and in the mean time your rival hero on the shard takes it over and you lose GG!I also found the combat really dull and boring. I hate strategy game where the units you face aren't concerened with their own life.  As in I hate facing A.I. that's more then willing to kamakaze themselves just so you lose a unti, rahter than strategically move around the board so they don't get flanked or ambushed.  But instead they will charge in the middle of 3 units just to take out that weak archer or shaman and the enemies die next turn because they bum rushed in the middle of your army just for the sake of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. (Also why I hate FIre Emblem and love FF Tactics wayyy more, but anyways)No option to rebind the keys, the options to change the graphics was bare minimum, and the U.I. is underdeveloped, just doesn't provide enough information, like before you move to a square you could maybe scout it to see what level of enemies you could expect to face.  Or maybe in the "go to a a location" menu it could state what's in those locations when you hover your cursor over them, instead you just have to waste turn after turn poking around seeing what enemies you can face while the Enemy Heros take over the shard and Game Over. All in all a waste of time.

Played only 1 full turn on my current game and it crashed in the middle of the next.UPDATE 2, January 13 2014: Game is still crashing despite graphic settings fix.  Don't know why it can't just be consistent.UPDATE: TRY CHANGING THE DYNAMIC LIGHTING OPTION TO "6" INSTEAD OF RANDOM.  MUCH MORE STABLE WITH THIS GRAPHICS SETTING.  SWITCHED TO "RECOMMEND".OLD REVIEW FOLLOWS.Eador: Masters of the Broken GameI started playing this yesterday and have 13 hours in.  Unfortunately it is still glitchy.  Annoyingly, it likes to error out at the very end of the turn, so if you had a couple battles and an interesting random event... Sorry, gotta do it all over again.  And that cool random event will be something different next time.  So the mysterious magic items you see on the reward screen are never examined.If the game would at least quick-save at the end of every fight, I could give this a "recommend," despite the glitchiness.  If the game is ever fixed, it is definitely recommended.Consider this a public service announcement: Game still glitchy as of December 25th, 2013.  I hope it is fixed sometime.EDIT as of December 30th follows:I've added another 40 hours of playtime, despite glitches and restarts.  Its a testament to the fact that I really do like the game.  I try to limit the number of actions I take per turn, to give the game less opportunity to fail.  But I've hit 3 turns in a row where I've had to restart, and after lengthy battles.Like I said, if the game is fixed it will be great.  But until then it is a tantalizing tease of a game.  I'm not saying you should never buy it, but wait for it to be a working product.  Save yourself some time and frustration.I intend to update this review in the future when the game is playable.People who disagree with this 100% factual review must be out of their mind, or reading reviews to discredit rather than fixing their game.

												Good strategic game. The main advantage is that there are a lot of possibilities. There is no unbalanced/unbeatable combination of units, so you can play the game your style. For example Forests is good cover against ranged attacks and hills give you an advantage in melee fights. You don't have to kill all units, you can also reduce their moral to zero or reduce their stamina (that won't grant you the victory, but makes it way easier to kill them ;))The Game is still a little bit buggy and freezes sometimes when you start a new shard and you have to play a different shard instead.The Game develops slowly, you have to conquer a shard and as reward you get plans to build new buildings. You get the first tier II units after 3-4 shards.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												While many of the serious bugs have been resolved a year later, a few game-breaking bugs do remain (albeit the ones listed above do not).Gameplay balance remains an issue, and it inherently leads to a very grindy game.So it remains a diamond in the rough.---After almost a year, this game remains a bug-ridden hellhole, with very little tactical or strategic balance at most levels of the gameplay. I'm almost tempted to say the bugs are worse now than they were a year ago.Some bugs include:- if more than one battle of any kind occurs on the map, no other battles can occur. They immediately auto-resolve with both sides being listed as dead despite not being dead.- The AI cannot conquer any terrain where it has to fight player guards. Neither the guards will die nor will the province be conquered.Some gameplay issues include:- In campaign mode, it is entirely possible for the capitol of an AI to be guarded by 9 centaurs. Centaurs are powerful tier 2 units. If this occurs in the first or second mission, you have been given a near-impossible task, as the gameplay elements that allow you to defeat centaurs are not available until later in the game. You can, of course, surrender, and keep playing. This, and similar balance issues, remain a frustrating element of the game.- Starting units are worthless and unless you follow certain strategies or know what you're doing, you're likely to be stuck in your home province for many, many turns.All of this is incredibly sad, as the game's core concept is pretty great. The programming and game design, however, are lackluster and poor. A great game marred by poor design.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Eador: Masters of the Broken World is a great game if you have a lot of time to spend, and do not mind a slow progression curve. Presenting you with a strategy game set in a detailed world broken up into multiple shards, you can spend your time gathering land and power to eventually find one of many endings. It is a big game, full of strategic decisions and plenty of things you can explore, find, and control. It is one of the largest games in scale that I have seen so far, which is both good and bad. Good, because, of course. That's more game for you to play in, and bad because all that scale takes a lot of time to get through. So much time that you may not have enough in your schedule to make good progress in it - I have over 80 hours in it, and I have not yet completed the campaign. As much as I like the scale, the shattered vibrant world, the astral mechanics and the immersive soundtrack, it has issues that it doesn't need to have.The world in Eador is based on shards, with each shard being a whole new map to explore and conquer, and every one you conquer brings you a new building or advantage you can take along to the next. You gain astral energy based on how much of the world is in your possession, and how many people worship you, the astral spirit/master controlling the place. The problem here is that every single shard has you build up your forces from practically nothing. You can spend energy to bring some basics, but it is never really enough to skip through the early game and expensive. Plus, who knows what else you may want your energy for? Eador plays much more like several similar skirmish maps than a long unified campaign. Yet, there is throughout it all a large storyline, from world to world, where you can spend time talking to the other masters or decide to engage them, change things that have long term effects far past the one world you're in, or otherwise find out more about the game's world. While in the game itself, there are a lot of random and semi-random events as well. The world feels as if it is actually a world, rather than just a game through these. The soundtrack is very well done, and it is easy enough to forget about time and spend several hours to take over another shard and advance past it. But it has issues, as mentioned. It is imperfect, with occasional crashes and some balance issues making it very difficult to progress at times, as well as some design decisions, whether intentional or not, leading to some choices being just plain better than others. Out of all this, the worst of it is when your opponent gets a random event that allows them to have a guard dragon, while you are still in the earliest levels. There is no way to defeat a dragon at that point without a lot of grinding experience on your hero and luck.The opposing AI is rather poor, and at times does not seem to even understand the basics of gameplay, which is sad as you will be spending a lot of time beating on said AI. Both the other masters and the neutrals tend to be like that, sadly. The battles being on a tiny, simplistic map that shows that combat is not the game's strong point. But you're likely not buying this for the combat. If you're buying Eador, you're doing it for the strategy, the long term plans, the vibrant world, and all the good things it has. Try to not let its faults get to you, and you will be able to spend litterally days on it without any regret. But if you do not have time, patience, or are not that much into strategy and similar 4X games, you may not enjoy it. For those who do enjoy those things, here's for you.

												In the tutorial, I was exploring with my Scout and his army.I got an event in which I can "rest in the forest"So I choose "Rest" to see what will happen...While resting I get attacked by 2 Ghosts. There is no option to retreat, no option to negotiate, no option for protective measures. I was forced into combat.The 2 Ghosts were COMPLETELY IMMUNE to physical damage. I only had 3 Magic Missiles on my hero. I killed only one of them. The other Ghost had half hit points and he killed my entire army of 7 units including the hero because he was completely immune to physical attacks and the tutorial does not allow you to have any magic units in your army.Great game design! How about an event that forces you to fight a Tier 2 unit that is completely immune to the most basic damage type with no way for you to counter it? No strategy, no exploitation of weakness, no need to use your brain at all. Just watch one low tier unit slaughter your army because the developers don't know what STRATEGY and testing means. I swear is was absolutely hilarious watching this one ghost guy kill a whole army by himself! WTF!In every other tactical strategy game, "Ghost" type units can RESIST physical damage, maybe have 50% resistance or even 70%... not ♥♥♥♥in 100%! (unless magic attacks are abundant from the start, which they are NOT in this game)The rest of the game can basically be summed up in one phrase: Quantity over qualityLots of options, so much to do, but poorly balanced, poorly tested and deeply flawed on a strategic level.5/10 Game could have been great if more attention was given to unit design and level up progression of heroes and units.EDIT: Of course they released a sequel (standalone expansion). Still in early access, but if it has the same units and gameplay as this game, you can pretty much expect the same thing: More quantity, less quality

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Okay, I enjoy this game. I enjoy it alot. I have dumped alot of time into the game. If you like Strategy/RPG mix overall I think this game is something to look at. I won't hide the fact that the game is still buggy even after being out for a year, but the developers have been patching the game non-stop since it came out April 2013.The Ugly:Okay this game still has bugs, for some people game breaking bugs, and for others bugs that are iritating enough that can make it painful to play the game sometimes. The game was released last April almost completely unplayable, and over the past year it has improved for the major part. Yet I won't gloss over the fact that their is still alot wrong with the game.The Bad:The game probably is not all that balanced. Their are 4 tiers of units, and some T4 units could trample an entire army. Not all of the Hero classes are balanced. Their are 4 of them, but they all are playable. It will be nice to see what the game is like in the future.The Good:Did I mention patching? The developers still care about the game. They have been patching it a while, and still patch it. There is alot in this game, alot of units, alot of choice. Alot of lore burried deep within a rough exterior. The game does not look half bad. The game is not fast paced, but is the type of game you can start playing, and come back between turns as you do something else, but will also keep you wanting to play "one more turn" when things are getting good or you near to beating another map. The developers have recently added a boat load of new units and spells, and have dropped hints are future expansion to the game.Is the game, worth $19.99? Its a hard sell considering how buggy it can still be. I do thing its a hard sell, but I've enjoy the time I've dumped  into the game and I do appreciate the patches that have gone into it. The game has gotten good, and hopefully it will cotinue getting better.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												*Nominated for Steam's “Game that never stops kicking your b*tt” Award*This game is relentless. Uncaring. Unforgiving. And it will always find more creative ways to humiliate you. Punish you. At first, you think you're such a tough guy/gal, because you've been playing tactical games for decades, so you turn up the difficulty and start your first game. You are told you are a God, and you feel like you'll own this world. You laugh at the tutorial, thinking "please... this is not my first barbecue here, enough with the holding-my-hand gameplay, give me a real challenge." And surely these goblins are just cannon fodder for xp right? Think again. They will tear you apart. On your first battle. It's like getting slapped in the face and get told to get back to your seat. You slowly realize how dangerous this first world is. And then it dawns on you : "Wait... I... actually may lose before completing my first shard..." Careful planning, pacing, and never under-estimating choices become a necessity. For survival. After a few hours, just when you think you're starting to get the hang of it... you have this strategy all prepared... you have these old units getting tougher and tougher... Then the game crushes you again. It never takes much : it takes one wrong move on the battlefield ; it takes one daring click during a random event ; it takes one management mistake for your equipment or fortress...Soon you're back to the main menu and a lesson in humility has been learned. You click "expert" difficulty (default gameplay stats) wishing you had the guts to click "beginner" instead... but there's always a bit of pride left in you, isn't there? And then you're off to another b*tt-kicking. This is not a bad thing. This is actually a great thing. Your choices matter. All of them. Because each time you're wrong, you fail. And each victory, each captured shard, is a real hard-fought battle. It's an endeavour. A real achievement. Overcoming the odds. Until that moment when the game will find another way to mess with everything you thought you had mastered, in a way you never saw coming.This game is a tactical boot-camp. Russian style. Be warned.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												Recommend if you have loads of time to burn.I want to like this game but it is a bit of grind in the campaign. You'll invest a few hours on a shard to move to the next one just to unlock one more building. The game is fairly challenging which is good. Your lands are easily conquered and require your constant vigilance. Lands also revolt and succeed and so you send your limited units over to smack them down. Meanwhile, other lords are conquering the lands you just left. There's a good amount of random events that benefit or hurt you. There's also a fair amount of bugs that will hurt or annoy you like enemy units that are dropped to 0 hp but don't die. There also seems to always be a non-zero probability to lose a battle when you have an overwhelming force on auto-battle.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Eador: Masters of the Broken World is a great game if you have a lot of time to spend, and do not mind a slow progression curve. Presenting you with a strategy game set in a detailed world broken up into multiple shards, you can spend your time gathering land and power to eventually find one of many endings. It is a big game, full of strategic decisions and plenty of things you can explore, find, and control. It is one of the largest games in scale that I have seen so far, which is both good and bad. Good, because, of course. That's more game for you to play in, and bad because all that scale takes a lot of time to get through. So much time that you may not have enough in your schedule to make good progress in it - I have over 80 hours in it, and I have not yet completed the campaign. As much as I like the scale, the shattered vibrant world, the astral mechanics and the immersive soundtrack, it has issues that it doesn't need to have.The world in Eador is based on shards, with each shard being a whole new map to explore and conquer, and every one you conquer brings you a new building or advantage you can take along to the next. You gain astral energy based on how much of the world is in your possession, and how many people worship you, the astral spirit/master controlling the place. The problem here is that every single shard has you build up your forces from practically nothing. You can spend energy to bring some basics, but it is never really enough to skip through the early game and expensive. Plus, who knows what else you may want your energy for? Eador plays much more like several similar skirmish maps than a long unified campaign. Yet, there is throughout it all a large storyline, from world to world, where you can spend time talking to the other masters or decide to engage them, change things that have long term effects far past the one world you're in, or otherwise find out more about the game's world. While in the game itself, there are a lot of random and semi-random events as well. The world feels as if it is actually a world, rather than just a game through these. The soundtrack is very well done, and it is easy enough to forget about time and spend several hours to take over another shard and advance past it. But it has issues, as mentioned. It is imperfect, with occasional crashes and some balance issues making it very difficult to progress at times, as well as some design decisions, whether intentional or not, leading to some choices being just plain better than others. Out of all this, the worst of it is when your opponent gets a random event that allows them to have a guard dragon, while you are still in the earliest levels. There is no way to defeat a dragon at that point without a lot of grinding experience on your hero and luck.The opposing AI is rather poor, and at times does not seem to even understand the basics of gameplay, which is sad as you will be spending a lot of time beating on said AI. Both the other masters and the neutrals tend to be like that, sadly. The battles being on a tiny, simplistic map that shows that combat is not the game's strong point. But you're likely not buying this for the combat. If you're buying Eador, you're doing it for the strategy, the long term plans, the vibrant world, and all the good things it has. Try to not let its faults get to you, and you will be able to spend litterally days on it without any regret. But if you do not have time, patience, or are not that much into strategy and similar 4X games, you may not enjoy it. For those who do enjoy those things, here's for you.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												i love eador. this or any version. i won't deny that masters of the broken world has it's flaws, but overall i love it. there are plenty of reviews out there that will tell you what can be improved about this game, so i just want to focus on the postive aspects. what i really enjoy is that you build buildings in your main province or territory to recruit troops, upgrade units, boosts production, learn spells-basically everything in the game. if you want to buy your own armor and weapons, you can build the buildings associated with it, but beyond that, as you conquer more territories and hire guards to partol and protect them from potential uprisings or invaders, you can also build more buildings in those territories to do things like hire troops, buy items and learn spells from your capital territory without having to be there. you can also construct buildings in those provinces to boost production of the different currencies and other resources across your empire.i love that the different heroes allow for pretty widely varied playstyles. the scout/archer picks people off from a distance, the warrior is a one many army, the commander boosts his troops to near hero like levels and can have the largest number of troops on the battlefield, and the mage can be a range spellcaster, a healer, a necromancer with an army of the undead or a summoner of hellish hordes. the mage class is definitely my favorite. picking one hero at the start doesn't prevent you from getting the others later on, the cost goes up more and more, but you can keep buying new heroes and making more armies. there's a huge range of enemies to fight and the battlefield itself adds extra depth to the combat. hills slow down movement but provide extra defense for melee combat and extra range for archers, forests provide cover from range attacks and hinder movement. the swamps also slow down units and reduce defense for troops unlucky enough to be in there when attacked. seemingly every enemy you come across in the story can potentially be recruited and used to fight for you. if you don't want to play for hours to unlock the better weapons, armor, monsters, etc., you can play a quick match on a custom shard against custom opponents and you'll start with all the buildings unlocked and the freedom to explore any playstyle you want.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												An empire builder with terrible pacing. The visuals are beautiful, but the gameplay suffers from the fact that you can't field a mobile army unless you have a hero. Unfortunately, recruiting a hero beyond your first is prohibitively expensive, making the early parts of the game very boring or very frustrating depending on how you're progressing. Allowing players to march out troops without a hero or even allowing two free heroes at the start would help tremendously with the opening turns' dullness.Additionally, the game features a separate tactical map for combat. It starts promising, but it doesn't take long before units appear that completely disrespect the terrain and simply fly past your frontline troops to decimate your ranged units.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I put a good number of hours into this game as it seemed as though there is a lot of depth to it. This may well be the case but unfortunately I finally gave up with it due to the fact that it is so incredibly slow, clunky and badly made. The game mechanics are rather confusing and it really does a terrible job of letting you know what you are supposed to be doing. The tactical combat sections are also terrible. Tiny maps with big daft looking units that don't really offer much in the way of tactical options. Either your units are better or the enemies are. It's all pretty dull stuff, which is a shame really as I tend to like this type of game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Really awesome game that captures fantasy and the idea of being a demigod perfectly. The combat is amazing and really fun, the graphics look great, the replayablity is insane, the random events are fun and well written. The game is really deep and extensive as well, with so many things to manage, upgrade and decide it's just a pure joy to play. Oh, and if you ever played Eador before, this game is literally a 3rd remake of it in it's custom games. With even more content with the DLC. The mixed status and the negative reviews are due to the I guess boring campaing, which is why people complain about not keeping their units and upgrades from shard to shard. The thing is, the campaign is supposed to just be a side thing, The best way to play this game is to go into a custom game, set up your settings, and then enjoy hours of fun as you attempt to conquer your shard.

I'd love to see a sequel that is similar but gives me a chance!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												An empire builder with terrible pacing. The visuals are beautiful, but the gameplay suffers from the fact that you can't field a mobile army unless you have a hero. Unfortunately, recruiting a hero beyond your first is prohibitively expensive, making the early parts of the game very boring or very frustrating depending on how you're progressing. Allowing players to march out troops without a hero or even allowing two free heroes at the start would help tremendously with the opening turns' dullness.Additionally, the game features a separate tactical map for combat. It starts promising, but it doesn't take long before units appear that completely disrespect the terrain and simply fly past your frontline troops to decimate your ranged units.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												i love eador. this or any version. i won't deny that masters of the broken world has it's flaws, but overall i love it. there are plenty of reviews out there that will tell you what can be improved about this game, so i just want to focus on the postive aspects. what i really enjoy is that you build buildings in your main province or territory to recruit troops, upgrade units, boosts production, learn spells-basically everything in the game. if you want to buy your own armor and weapons, you can build the buildings associated with it, but beyond that, as you conquer more territories and hire guards to partol and protect them from potential uprisings or invaders, you can also build more buildings in those territories to do things like hire troops, buy items and learn spells from your capital territory without having to be there. you can also construct buildings in those provinces to boost production of the different currencies and other resources across your empire.i love that the different heroes allow for pretty widely varied playstyles. the scout/archer picks people off from a distance, the warrior is a one many army, the commander boosts his troops to near hero like levels and can have the largest number of troops on the battlefield, and the mage can be a range spellcaster, a healer, a necromancer with an army of the undead or a summoner of hellish hordes. the mage class is definitely my favorite. picking one hero at the start doesn't prevent you from getting the others later on, the cost goes up more and more, but you can keep buying new heroes and making more armies. there's a huge range of enemies to fight and the battlefield itself adds extra depth to the combat. hills slow down movement but provide extra defense for melee combat and extra range for archers, forests provide cover from range attacks and hinder movement. the swamps also slow down units and reduce defense for troops unlucky enough to be in there when attacked. seemingly every enemy you come across in the story can potentially be recruited and used to fight for you. if you don't want to play for hours to unlock the better weapons, armor, monsters, etc., you can play a quick match on a custom shard against custom opponents and you'll start with all the buildings unlocked and the freedom to explore any playstyle you want.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Eador Cons1: You have to restart from scratch every level.2: Instead of having more intelligent IA they just throw more resources and units at them really early on.3: Game has a auto resolve button, but it's broken at best. Ex archer heroe with peasant army v dragons=win archer heroe with peasant army v wolf pack= lose.4: recent update introduced invalid pointer error which causes the game to quit working when certain game events happen it can be worked around, but it's annoying. 5: The game overall is really slow to get going.Pros1: Every level you can pick a different route to go (different heroes, units, buildings, spells, good or evil, etc.)2: You have to plan ahead when choosing buildings to create a good army.3: Random events that can be good or bad, and you get to decide how to respond to them instead of just watching them happen.4: Unit trees (good, neutral, evil) are balanced out.5: You can have guards to defend your lands so you don't always have to make your heroes backtrack to deal with random events. (Which is really helpful during war times.) Guards also have effects on the lands they are stationed in.All in all it's a good game if you can stand restarting every level, but I wouldn't recommend it till they fix the (invalid pointer error) problem.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												I love turn based strategy games.  This game looks and feels a lot like Heroes of Might & Magic, but it has some flaws that holds it down from it’s true potential.  I’m writing this review for the TBS fans that know what they are looking for, and noting the exact flaws that ruin the game.There are four tiers of strength for your recruitable units.  Each recruitable unit can level up.  However, no matter what high level they attain, they are really no match for the next higher tier unit.  No units can be resurrected, which can be infuriating when your tier 1, level 10 infantry is eliminated by a tier 3, level 0 archer in one strike.  I tried to cycle through my troops by only using my low levels to fight low level battles, but then you realize that your higher tiers would rather benefit from the experience, as they will need all they can get when they have to take on tier 4 enemies.  On top of that, the opponent AI will always bee-line to your weakest and most exploitable units first.  Battles have to be sought out, but are abundant.  The problem is low level encounters are just as rare as high level encounters.  All encounters are preset, and you can choose when to take on the encounter.  You might find yourself scouring the lands trying to find goblins for your tier 1, level 0s to knock out, wasting many turns in the process.  The best way to level up your army is for them to see combat head on, which makes it tough to build up solid armies without losing a few in the process.  I found myself sometimes recruiting low levels as simple cannon fodder or bait.  No units have a ‘taunt’ ability, so no unit can be used for ‘tanking.’ This greatly hurts the whole point of playing as a warrior type CO, and puts heavy armor defense infantry in a tough spot.  Most units can run or fly circles around them.  Terrain does play a role in mobility and stat adjustments, but not so much that it becomes a game changer.  Battles ultimately end up being very lopsided, with little actual strategy.If it wasn’t for the core of the strategy being flawed, it would be a fantastic gem.  The graphics are very pleasing to the eye.  The soundtrack is limited and repetitive like an old console game, but can be turned off.  The interface may look intimidating at first, but it is simply spread out and unconsolidated, which doesn’t affect gameplay.  I only recommend it to those with a tremendous amount of patience and time on their hands.  Expect campaigns to take many hours at a time, and anticipate never being able to take on many battles due to the limits of what army you can develop.  In short, expect disappointment, but do your best with what you have.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												I'm struggling to find words insulting enough to convey how terrible this game is. It's simply a disaster on all levels.Getting the game to run initially is a struggle by itself. The game files get flagged by AVG (something I've never seen before with a Steam title. After that, the game won't run because the game process is not killed and Steam will report an error. Even after forcibly terminating the process, steam still thinks you are running it. Ultimately you have to forcibly terminate Steam itself to fix it. Once you finally get into the game, things get even more frustrating. Let me cover some key points to give a general idea of why I think the game is a POS. First you customize your profile as lord- pick a portrait, emblem color, name etc- however this is mostly pointless because the only part of the customization that is retained is the name and emblem. I picked a cool portrait to suit my roleplaying preference, changed colors to black and white, but in the game my portrait reverted to the default one and the character model is fixed to all red armor with a particularly douchey looking haircut. The games inability to let the player roleplay doesn't stop there either. You equip your guy with a nice shiny Axe and a shield, but the model does not change and in battle he uses a spear and sword. I've seen more roleplaying value in games that aren't even roleplaying games.No UI scaling- Yeah this game doesn't have it. If you are like me and many others that want to play at a decent resolution, then prepare to squint your eyes at the tiny UI or keep a magnifying glass in one hand as you play. There's really no excuse as to why a game like this is lacking such a rudimentary feature. The combat- If you would call it that) is incredibly boring and lifeless. It's about as satisfying as peeling a potato. The animations are out of sync with the combat actions. The floating text and repercussions of an action happen before it has even been executed in a rather strange and detached way. Swinging a sword at an enemy looks and sounds like you've just slapped someone with a stick of celery. The combat lacks any meaningful impact and the enemies fall down in the most generic way shortly before they vaporize into a bunch of sticks ?When a battle ends there is no reaction at all from your army, no war-cries, no chants, they just stand there like stunned-mullets like it never even happened. The battle map is so one-dimensional and generic looking. It doesn't make an effort to show any creativity and just slaps a bunch of hexes together on some slightly modulated ugly looking terrain. I'd say the best part about this game is it's music, and even that's pretty average. Other than that, It's just a horrible uninspired, boring and lackluster approach to the genre with no redeeming value. In fact I can't think of a single thing this game does right. Such a waste.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												I don't know what people's problem with this game is, it's pretty sweet to be honest. I don't know why there aren't more reviews or why the ones it does have are mixed.It plays like Civ 5, but you choose a hero (mage, ranger, warrior) and you deck him out to take out enemies. You can get more heros later if you can afford them and deck them out and send to war as well. You recruit soldiers to build armies your heros can command, and there are lots of cool fantasy units you can get. There are casters and healers and tanks and archers you can unlock. More fantastical things are in too, like faries and ogres for example, if you conquer neighboring settlements, which you can do through bribes, diplomacy, quests or violence.Technology is a little weird. You unlock new solder types not through a tech tree so much but by building things in your towns. Building upgrades and types offer higher tier soldiers and different soldier types as well as spells your dudes can use in combat. Army composition is important, you will take morale hits if you put in a bunch of paladins with zombies for example, so you want to watch that and recruit accordingly. I got this game on sale but this title is worth the $20; as far as the dlc I bought it with the game so I can't really tell what all that added or not as I haven't looked at it seperately. It's only a few bucks though so may as well pick it up as well imo. I bought this as a cheaper alternative to Age of Wonders and Heros of Might and Magic, so I can't really compare it to them, but judging this game by itself I would say it is a fantastic game by its own merits.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I must admit all the negative reviews put me off, but most of the top rated reviews were all positive. So I decided to pirate the game to see what it was like. I can honestly say that it was extremely fun and I decided to buy it the next day. For those who are new to the genre or maybe even the game, I recommend using beginner difficulty and playing the tutorial to get a grasp of the game mechanics. It's a fun game that requires you to think tactically on the battlefield and strategically about what 'shard' you want to conquer. It can be difficult at times, especially if you get a bad starting position, however this can be overcome when you get used to the game. However losing a shard isn't game over, as long as you have more than your opponent you're still in with a chance. Look if you're still not sure pirate the game, don't like it don't buy it, if you do like it buy it, simple. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												I really want to like this game, but it just ends up being shy of good. The game has issues with bugs creaping in, but the developers are generally pretty quick at addressing them. Unfortunately you rarely get a fully working game. As old bugs are squashed, new ones creep in. Also, some bugs just don't go away, the worst is the bug where you can't end your turn. You're required to basically sacrifice your next turn by converting it into 'auto combat'. In many cases this just results in you losing the battle. This means that 5-10% of your battles you are required to reload, purely because they won't/can't fix this bug.There's three aspects to the game. A campaign-wide strategy, a map strategy, and tactical maps/tactics in small combats. Each one is flawed.The Campaign-wide strategy could be very cool, as you earn astral power to augment your next map start, and you selectively choose what building upgrades you can get. Unfortunatly the astral power aspect is far too weak to have any reasonable changes on your map starts. So every map you start (which will be 10's if not 100's of times in a single campaign) is exactly the same thing. It gets repetitive.The map strategy involves taking provinces and as you progress to diposing 1-N enemies on the map, but once you take a province you can instantly plop down a guard for the garrison, which is 1/10th the cost of the troops you would normally have to buy, and regularly a lot better than any troops anyone can produce. This means the game behoves rushing early on and plopping down guards, two of which the AI gains bonuses and cheats to accomplish.Finally, the tactical combat is exeedingly simplistic. The AI does the same thing irrespective of the map or your compliment. There is no concept of "threatened zones" around your characters, so AI troops will run through your line and attack things behind you, turning the game into just balling your troops up, and your tactics are limited by the kharma system.The game has a "kharma" system that is based on your actions and the results of the campaign, which would seem like a good idea. Unfortunately, the kharma system limits what troops you can acquire or use, and these limits have absolutely zero relation with your actions. The "good" kharma units are slow and expensive, while the "evil" kharma units are generally glass cannons. Since your world map size/complement would dictate which tactics you would want to do, the strategic aspects of kharma basically have negative correlary to the tactical aspects of kharma. Combined with the fact you're limited in the number of units you can build at any rank/tier, this means that if you start in a small shard with the zerg units (which since every shard is the same, is almost always the best early option) you're now locked out of the other units.The concept of the game is great, but in practice the limits on troops, building ranks, and the failing of the astral campaign options results in a very tedious game where your choices are generally limited not by any sort of story or strategy, but just purely pragmatic necessities.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												UPDATE 1/2016:A lot of the bugs seem to be fixed, though a few might remain. I'm switching this to a *very cautious* thumbs up. (By the way, my hours in the game are exaggerated. One of the many bugs is that when the game crashed, it didn't end the process in the task manager. So, I once had the process running for a week straight, adding a couple hundred hours to my play time).ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW:So many bugs! I really really want to enjoy this game. And for long stretches, I do enjoy it... and then a gamebreaking bug causes all of my progress to be lost. This happens over and over again. I keep coming back, so at its heart it is a good game. Every time there is a patch to fix a bug, several new bugs pop up in its place. Most recently, they put out a big patch, calling it free DLC, and supposedly fixed bugs. It introduced an obvious, gamebreaking bug right up front that makes the game unplayable (enemy units won't die, they just sit on the battlefield at 0 health).Here is a list of some other bugs I've encountered in previous builds, some of which may still be present (I don't know, since the game is unplayable on the first shard now)1) I attacked another master, and won the final battle to take the shard. This results in a "game over" screen (this ruined my longest campaign, and even happened when I went to beat a different shard first, then returned to that master).2) My provinces are invincible. An enemy master will defeat my guards at a province, then retreat the next turn, with the province still under my control and my guards at full health3) I attack a province and end up in a mirror match, where I control both of my identical armies against one another. No matter which side wins, I both win and lose the battle. 4) Game freezing and crashing to desktop immediately after conquering a shard. It goes to the main astral screen, the conquered shard comes towards my shard, and the game crashes as soon as they merge. 5) The enemy AI completely forgetting to play the game. I once took over an entire master's shard with the enemy hero having never been beyond one hex of his capital. This was on a large map.I cannot recommend this game in its current state. It's been a year of heartache for me, since I want to play through a campaign so badly, and I keep trying, but it's just getting worse.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that I've been playing all types of strategy games for nearly 25 years.  This game has potential.  I found myself trying to figure out how to reach the higher level content once I managed to level my hero up.  Many of the quests were extremely hard at the beginning stages of the game and added to the frustration of leveling up.  Basic units are no match to even the most beginning level "monsters".The economy is unbalanced.   Unit maintenance is very high in relation to the amount of coin that you bring in from provinces.  Building costs are low which allows for quick building.   This will allow you to access units for purchase fairly quickly.  However, it doesn't seem to matter that much because there is a logistical issue with your hero only being able to hold 4 troop types at lower levels.  Even after leveling up to level 4, a hero still can only hold 4 troop types.  It is very difficult to level your units and keep your favorite units around.  Combat is unbalanced.I'm not sure if it's a bug, but my garrison was transferred to another province when an uprising occured in that province.  I would expect the garrison to stand and fight.The loot part of the game was very cool at first.  But there's no originality to the items.  Many of them are common low level items that don't help out too much.  Most of the game is loot based with low drop rates.There are several bugs that cause the game to freeze/crash in the middle of the game.  This is not a huge issue though considering the game saves every 2 seconds.If this game got some balance tweeks, item updates, bug fixes it would be a much more fun game to play.  It feels like the developers wanted to portray the look and feel of a 4x strategy game with all of the bells and whistles , but forgot the underlying basic game mechanics.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Eador is billed as a stategy game and tries to combine Empire building 4x themes with turn based 'tactical' battles. Although the ideas are sound the execution is pretty bad. Everything seems a bit off at first and the feeling only grow the more you play it. Call it lack of polish or simply the mark of an 'indie' studio, the result is still the same...Not very fun. The tactical battles as gimped with an impossibly small field of battle (units are constantly getting in each others way if you have more than 5-6 units and archers and mages can wipe you out from across the map) and poor unit balance. Even on the easiest difficulty level the fights go from very easy to frustrating. Before the battle the game gives you an indication of how tough a fight will be but even fights that "You will win easily" can be a total wipe unless you use all your units in perfect coordination. i wish I would have had the willpower to play more to see if it improves but the game is simply not fun...

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I've never been able to complete this game due to the game crippling "pointer errors" which regularly occur. They are a game ending, campaign crippling, bug that despite being reported numerous times over the years hasn't been fixed.Worse, an expansion for this game just came out... so odds are these pointer errors will never be fixed. Since the expansion is using the same game engine it is highily likely that these unfixed pointer errors will still occur even in the expansion.It is a shame really. Aside from the pointer errors which prevent you from ever finishing the campaign and experiencing all of its extremely well written story its overall a great game with some awesome concepts and I'd recommend it, but when it can't be completed, never gets fixed, and then the company moves on to making another game using the same (likely still broken) game engine... I can't recommend that to anyone.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Eador is a game I have put off reviewing for quite some time and sitting down to play it I can remember why.Difficult to learn, difficult to master, best sum up Eador.If you are familiar with Heroes of Might and Magic then Eador is a familiar beast and just like those games you control a single hero who in turn controls an army. You are not limited to just one hero however and as long as you have the resources your army can be as big as you like. I am going to assume however that you are unfamiliar with HoM&M and even if you are, Eador is a different beast altogether. It's main gimmick is shards, that is each map is its own contained world so when you conquer one shard you move onto the next.The game also features an ambigious moral choice system and certain units do or do not like being teamed up with others. Holy Paladins for example are not pleased by having to work with blood sucking vampires and such combinations will affect morale. Let morale get too low and units will flee the battlefield.Already you can see a lot of systems are in play in this game and it isn't a bad game either. Complex doesn't have to mean 'bad' or 'begineer-unfriendly' but many things are randomized. You might get a start location with nearby provinces you have little chance of taking over and no resources to bribe them with. A province by the way is akin to a second city or to extending your domain so basically you want them if you can get them.I really could go on and on about every little system but a game stands or falls on one thing. Is it fun? For me Eador is middle ground. It is not a bad game at all and if you like games such as Civilization 5 or Endless Legend you will find yourself slowly adapting to Eador but for me I grew up on Heroes of Might & Magic so I want to love Eador and instead I find myself being SUPER ANNOYED at the game lying to me so much!3 Medusas? Yeah it'll be fine, we'll slaughter them. Lied the game shortly before I reloaded my last save.6 Peasants? We stand no chance! Lied the game again and I wiped them out with no issues.Lying is a harsh word but that is certainly what it feels like at times. The game will tell you that wizards can attack at range, but forgets to tell you that they need a wand to do so. A wizard is a hired hero and hiring is expensive so if your wizard doesn't come with a wand, your hosed. You have to spend more money to build a shop that sells wands. The game will tell you that a unit has a certain range like 3 or 4 but you get into a fight and it forgets to mention all the modifiers that effect the range like trees or hills.And this is the begineer difficulty, with tutorials turned on! As you get better at the game you learn to ignore the lies as you have a good idea of what kills what and who to fight or who to avoid but I can't help but feel like Eador sabotaged itself. This game should be as big as the remade Kings Bounty games with over a million copies shifted or something I mean this game is good enough to be a Civ5 contender, but due to the steep learning curve I imagine many people are just turned off and stop playing, I know I did.Music is more of background noise, I honestly mentally tuned it out. Sound effects are funny, spiders sounds like jewels falling down an escalator but as I always say about sound effects, they are not the biggest factor. Graphics? Game looks wonderful! Really, the art is great it really is and their is so much of it you won't take it all in until after a few hours of playing.Overall Eador is a niche game for a niche market and that is a huge shame. I stand by what I said when I said this game should be up there as a contender for Civ5 but as it stands many will have looked Eador over for Endless Legend and I personally think Eador is the better game but its amazing the difference some handholding and a tutorial can do.The game does have a manual but I think that should be within the game itself like Civ5's civilpedia. I can't recommend this game to the majority of people but if you read this far then you will have a good idea if this is the kind of game for you or not, for most people they will struggle to get into this game and when they do the small playerbase will struggle to keep them.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

You use these heros,that command armies, to take out your foes. I get that using mortals to do your dirty work is what is normally propagated for strategy games, since Gods are "far too powerful" to be harmed. number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												I've never seen so much needless repetition in a game, which sucks because with a few tweaks Eador would be superb! But you will quickly see (within the first non-tutorial map) that the game is incredibly repetitive and grindy.There is a concept of exploring provinces which is good but the execution is bad: Exploring takes many turns and you have to tell your heroes to "Continue exploring" every. single. turn. You may even get more than one hero to do this, so you will be clicking OK a lot. This really should be automatic.You can then "visit" the locations you have found while exploring, which you will usually do this with your strongest hero. When visiting locations, any scouting information you accrued is lost and you're given no indication of the fight difficulty (if there is one) until you spend a turn. Both issues could have been covered in a 'are you sure?' prompt when selecting locations.You're supposed to hire heroes and support them with an army. But I found it much easier to just hire a tough warrior hero and equip them with all the stuff you find from visiting locations. After a while they become invincible and can just stomp on everything. Armies are too expensive/upgrading heroes via equipment is too cheap.Managing your kingdom is a horrible experience. You can only reinforce one village guard and build one building in one province per turn. Your kingdom will typically consist of dozens of provinces, making this incredibly tedious and difficult to keep track of. These limits could be removed.Finally, there are too many random events. They can fire off for multiple provinces every. single. turn. Many events have multiple stages, depending on what choice you make. Do you care that there is a minor event in the insignificant province of Backwater Dump that might affect the citizens in some vague, indiscernable manner? The game believes you should. These events could have been more rare and had a larger impact.So, Eador is entertaining and has great concepts but terrible execution. I can't recommend it when there are better games like it out there (Age of Wonders, Heroes of Might and Magic 3/5).

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												You can blame me for not playing it enough, but after over 10h of playtime, the game did not get me hooked, not at all.And i honestly think it's sad. The art is amazing, the sound atmospheric, the story... might be interesting, i can barely tell though and i think you can see the love and thought which went into this game, there are a lot of nice concepts packed into it. But, for me, the actual gameplay is so horrible that i don't even want to touch it anymore despite all the things that seem so nice about it.Here is why: I like turn based strategy games, i've been playing Heroes of Might and Magic (oh no, so mainstream?!) since decades, tried every installement and Eador reminds me very much of it. But, while Heroes is definetly not the fastest game, it has a pace i can go along with, its mechanics interlock well into one another (usually, not the same for all of them and all the titles), so it is nice to be invested in them, fighting your way through the campaign with what little things might be given to you, or watching your puny town thrive to a huge empire in an open game, or make to many or one big mistake and probably fail. I think, this is not the case in Eador. There is a lot you can do, but to me none of it felt like i was achieving anything. Spending dozens of turns to explore one area, most of which is delivered in text, sometimes fighting encounters, most of which appeared meaningless to me, sometimes dieing to a threat i couldn't even determine beforehand, or when the game even told me "this should be easy" and my units get one-hitted one after another, because i coudln't know better - more than once, but then, maybe i could have known better after the first time - careing less and less about the individual parts of the game because it feels so tedious, until i even started skipping most encounters and finaly stopped playing.So, i can't recommend it despite all its nice parts, because, after 10 hours of playtime, the game should have proven to me why i should care to carry on and not feel like a bunch of tasks i ought but not like to do to maybe get anywhere.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Aptly named title. With a significant overhaul this game could be something but in its current state it is badly "broken". This game will frustrate which makes it in many ways worse than a overtly bad game (at least with a bad game you could move on). As it is this one will have you going, "I wonder if it would be different if I tried this... or this...". It won't be. As things go this game prescribes too tightly the path you must take to be successful. Buy these units, not those ones, do things in this order and this way. Fight this, don't fight that until this, etc.As a huge fan of TBS and fantasy genre and long time (decades) player of same. I don't recommend this game. What I do recommend is that some developers out there learn from these guys mistakes and make the game that this should have been.EDIT/TLDR: Buy Age of Wonders III instead...
