content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Games are meant to be fun, not a chore to play.  This game is so close to being fun, but with the silly randomness of events and the rediculous amount of freebies the computer is awarded all aspects of enjoyment are gone.  I would rather say this game is recommended, but just cannot without that factor being present.  You need to first slowly, oh so slowly, level you starting hero in order to explore with you weak units in order to gain xp, gold and gems for encountering the computer opponents.  Then just when you can expand out farther the computer jumps in, starting at peace and hopefully remaining there long enough for you to gain units that can tackle the outer rings of territories.  Usually however you cannot get those units in enough time for the computer to declare war, and then steamroll over you with a hero that is 5 levels or more above yours and bringing in tier 3 (sometimes tier 4) units when you have only reached tier 2 units last turn.  Then on each level (shard) taking 2-3 hours to complete and then having no feeling of accomplishment ruins the game in my opinion.There is just something missing.  Games can, and should, be hard, in order to advance mastery of the game for good, hard fun to occur; at some level of hard however a game becomes stupid.  This game is at the border of this at this time.

												I played a long time this game, but I cannot reccomend it.Postitive:- Pretty for a tactical game- they have fixed most/all bugs- lot of differents units with unique abilities - complexe tactical gameNegative:- too oriented around the tactical combat (stratgic layer is interesting but most of your time will be spent doing combat)- hard to learn as you need to know each unit as some unit are totally overporwered and can wipe a whole army if you have nothing to counter them (example ghost are pretty much invulnerable against everything and are killed in one specific spell)- unit tier X are way more powerful than unit of the lower tier. number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												+ The overworld is nice looking. + Has a cute town upgrade system that shows the new buildings and technologies.+ Units and monsters are detailed and well animated, though some animations are over-long.+ / - Quite slow and very long. Each province needs capturing, then you can usually fight one or two side battles there straight away, then upgrade it (one building per turn only), then 'exploring' to quell overpopulation (about 5% explored per turn, totally automated, no actual walking around or exploration) which uncovers more battles. With over a dozen provinces per stage there is an awful lot of content, albeit drip-fed.- Unfulfilling, slow combat.- Even with a huge advantage, using the auto-battle will get half your force killed.- The battles really don't have much to do with 'strategy and tactics'. The battlefields are so small, so full of terrain and your army so comparatively huge that you almost run out of room to deploy them (leading to just plonking them down wherever you can), units get in each other's way, leading to fiddly, grindy crawls across a map dominated by choke points. Pretty shallow, more about numbers than anything else.If you like more board-gamey strategy games (like FF Tactics) then you might like this. But otherwise, don't bother.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Really dont get the difficulty settings in this game, I completed the first turtorial shard and it was super easy and then i tried the official first shard of the game and lost in first 6 turns so i lowered the difficulty, this time after 8 turns my units were finally able to attack and capture a province at which point the enemy showed up with 16 units and slaughterd me. So this time i tried on the easiest difficulty setting, i got a good hero leveled him up to 15 lasted for 3 hours just continusly building holding off the enemy but then another enemy player showed up who was apparently working with this player and they both attacked me from both sides and again I lost. I try defend i cant hire units to guard my province, the enemy with 1 province remaing can capture one of mine then instantly spawn an army of 10 highly trained archers to hold it for him while my hero can only hold 5 units. Its just redicolous and enraging. Sure i might not fully understand the game yet but i dont think a game should be this hard to pick up espically on the lowest difficulty setting when there are 8 settings to choose from. Otherwise im still disappointed nothing really carrys over from the shards so theres not much point trying to get the best items or units because you will just lose them. The shards are unoriginal and get repetitive very fast and the manual combat is boring, the maps are to small, after a certain point my archer hero could sit in a corner doing 12+ damage to anyone the moment they spawned, theres not enough tactics to manual combat to make it worth while, meanwhile the automatic combat seems to be just odds, my hero will say something like "this battle is going to be easy" yet all my units and hero will die to units they should of been able to kill easily. The whole game seemed very unbalanced which just ruined it for me. Definatly no match for some of the other games i love that are similar to this like Age of wonders. I cant recommend this game even though the tutorial was fun at i thought it was going to be amazing.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												This game is intriguing at first, and the tutorial even tricks you into thinking it will be fun. This is far from the reality of the game. In truth, even the beginning difficulty level is more frustrating than it is worth. I have tried multiple strategies from single to multiple heroes of different classes, conservative and liberal spending. None of it matters. By the time you get any momentum in the game you are harried by your opponent and relentlessly picked off. If resources were plentiful this would be an acceptable challenge as you could build your defenses, hire support, and actually dream to achieve something. The problem is that when this happens you are typically stretched. Conservative play is likely key, but to be honest - I don't f*ing play a game to sit around for hours twiddling my thumbs. Yes, it's strategy, but different people like different strategy. I for one do not like this one. I'd rather play Civ, or most any other tactics game. Save your time and money - and buy something better.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												This game is addictive, and the game play is fun, but they have some serious file handling errors.  Their file handling errors manifest it two ways.  The first is that if you try to attack the wrong shard the game will crash during the first save event.  The second is that if you try to attack the wrong enemy on a shard and the game will freeze.   I don’t know what’s going on, but this is pretty basic stuff.  It is kind of surprising that they could create the graphics and gameplay that they have and yet still not even manage programing 101 file handling issues.Here’s the use case that ruins the game for me.  I have three shards that I can attack.  Two of them will cause the game to crash during the first save event.  The third freezes every time I try to invade a territory controlled by the last of four enemies.  As such, there is now no way for me to even attempt to continue, let alone win, the game.  I guess that I could just kill off all of my heroes, dismiss all of my guards and troops, and then wait for the last enemy to conquer my castle, but who would want to do that?  Besides, there is no guarantee that surrendering this shard will allow for the creation of a shard that won’t crash.It looks like this game will be really fun someday.  But until they fix there file handling issues it is just frustrating.  As such, I wouldn’t recommend buying it until after they fix these bugs.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												The game has three tiers. On campaign level you conquer "shards" that give you new technologies and buildings, and compete with other NPCs. Each conquest happens on a map where you and your opponent have a castle, raise an army and fight for territories and resources. Finally, each fight happens on a tactical hex map.Campaign level is little more than a sequence of missions. You have some choice on what to attack next, but it does not matter much. It is extremely long, and most will stop playing before end. After playing 200 hrs I am about halfway.Arena level is fun, but NPC is not competitive - its just something to kill when you want the arena to end. The fun comes out of selecting a sequence of fights to level up your hero and your castle. Its somewhat similar to King's Bounty in play style - you pick fights, your hero levels up, you can now win harder fights, but there is no hurry to do something by set time.The tactical fights are reasonably entertaining, units have various spefical abilities and immunities that you have to keep in mind, there are spells, tile bonuces, fatigue influence etc.This would be a very good game, if not for bugs. Bugs! When I bought it a year ago, it was essentially unplayable, so I let it settle down for a while. Now it is somewhat better, but still, hourly crashes, NPC units endlessly going in circles, lockdowns, corrupted saves... when half of the challenge in a fight comes not from defeating an enemy, but from avoiding triggering the known bugs, the game definitely has quality problems... and if they didn't fix it by now I guess they never will.So... I am not recommeding it because of bugs.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												I tried to like this game, I really did, but the game is way too unbalanced and way too RNG dependent in order to be good.The game is pretty simple, kind of like some sort of Total War TBS. The object is to conquer shards by taking each enemy's capital, then move onto the next using advantages you gained in prior shards. Combat is grid based on a board with your soldiers. Each army is led by a hero and they all have their own special powers. Seems just like my kind of game.UNFORTUNATELY... the game is just broken in a number of ways. The shards are randomly generated and sometimes you can just get a trash start where it's very difficult to take neutral territories while the AI proceeds to take everything else. And on the topic of the AI... its cheating is in a league of its own. I've never seen anything like it in a game. The AI will do insane things like get tier 2 guard units before you even have access to them in game, all but insuring capturing their capital is nearly impossible. The same with spells. Tier 4 spells that one shot your entire army, super rare items, endless pools of gold... I've had the exact situation, where the AI was down to maybe 4 provinces and I had the entire map, but they would pop out heroes and full armies like it was nothing, all while their capital was defended by Centaurs, a tier 2 unit, that would utterly destroy even the best army I could muster since I hadn't even unlocked any tier 2 units!! By the way, this was on the 3rd from lowest difficulty, where the game still gives you advantages. Even when you don't get completely screwed with RNG and do pretty well all this cheating makes the game extremely tedious. Especially the guards. More often than not you need to grind up to beat them, sometimes for a long, long time. And you know what? In  the end, the AI cheating really doesn't make it that much harder. It just makes it take much, much longer.Add in some bugs plus a less than stellar UI and you have Eador in a nutshell. If it were less tedious it'd be a pretty fun game. As it is though? I suppose it's better than Warlock, but that's all I can really give it.

												Despite the ongoing support, consistent patching, and free mini-DLC, Masters of the Broken World is still Masters of the Broken Game (hahaha, I'm so good). content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												The tutorial took 3 hours and that was one of the most boring experiences I've ever had playing a video game.  I honestly can't think of a worse way to introduce your game to new players then what I just went through.  The basic game mechanics seemed backwards compared to every other game of this genre I've played.  Why would you make a move then wait for next turn to see how that move worked out, why doesn't it just happen now...  Other overworld mechanics appeared to exist only to increase the amount of "grinding" you could achieve as a player.  The combat mechanics were even worse, the basic UI had enough numbers floating around that you would generally have no idea what nay of them specifically meant.  The "guide" dialouge to tell you how difficult an encounter would be how wrong about as often as it was right.The music was repetitive beyond all measure, the sound effects and animations were amateurish. This game may have been a competitor with Heroes of Might and Magic 1 but nothing in that genre that's been created sense.  It is possible that if you're willing to give this game more of a chance then I did there is a good game waiting for you on the other end, but I can't imagine it.

												A complex and rich game worth your time if you like grinding and continually losing units to overpowered enemies - while the new units you buy are rank zero cannon fodder. You may build ONE building over your whole empire PER TURN, and your units recover ONE life point PER TURN. number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Well, some nice ideas, but done really really badly, and overall it quickly get's boring. Instead of something really creative, most of the hero progress/cash gain is thorugh random events generated by "exploring".  And realy while you theoretically can have many heroes for a HUGE part of each game you will walk with single army.  Basically because for one thing you will not be able to buy and maintain 2 heroes (even with easiest setting you will burn out starting gold too fast without building up the armies/heroes to conquer anything) And the difficulty of encounters is badly scaled - at the beginning you struggle in each fight, and then very suddenly you trample most enemies. There are still many bugs. For example before each encounter the game describes the opponent and tries to give some sumary on the chances. Not only the "estimate" is most often dead wrong ("no losses" is impossible and from some "hard" fights you come unscrathed). And that is particularily annoying because sometimes some bug causes the part of description with enemies  While the city building and expanse seems interesting and complex at first, it quickly becomes obvious it's really primitive. This is because in longer run most of the possible building choices are not really viable (You can build almost useless trash buildings or buy the few needed or save the cash)While your troops can gain experience and level, in most cases it affects them in pretty minimal way. And the game fight system is not setup in a way that would promote the "leveling" of units, as they are hard to level and easy to kill.Overall the game suffers from randomness in just about anything.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Found this game to be very repetitive and the only play style that worked for me was to be aggressive with the hero from the go. Since if you go slow, the enemy hero finds you and walks right through all your defences.  Whoever has the strongest hero wins especially with the weak units you use for most of the game, the hero can crush entire armies when he gets high enough and the mage class is useless for the most part. The campaign is like an endless restarting skirmish mode, where you start off the same each time with maybe a couple different enviromental effects and the possiblity of one more building which you earned last time. This gets old fast and it almost seems like you aren't making any progress with a vague reason to keep you going. So if you are wanting one or two skirmishes its ok, it also look and plays fine. Would however only say to get this game if its on sale to play a little to see what its like but for the most part its too repetitive for me.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Grab it on sale, if it sounds interesting to you. Otherwise... skip it.I have played 3 days worth on it and I honestly can't say any one part of it wants me to come back to try it again after letting it go for a while.Don't get me wrong, it has elements and aspects that are just begging to be a great game - but it is just not mixed well enough to make it there. Pieces of the game's RNG engine that determines the perks you gain by shards play havok with how to progress, making the game mixture so unevel you'll go through the game and realize you missed out on over two-thirds of the content for no real reason.It has so much, but so little to make you inclined to use it, its almost... forgettable.To me, that's kinda sad, especially since I can clearly remember the gameplay as to actually be that good, addictive "one more turn" element to it.It has promise, a massice selection of options, but the mixture on how its done makes it so uneven you'll forget what you could have done after you finish it.Its a passable game, about averate of what's to expect for the turn-based strategy - but nothing truly noteworthu  outside its concept. Some growth and development aspects that limit and help lean the player towards one style or another are truly good, but it cuts out so much of viable options thanks to the sheer quantity its such a shame on the balance scale of what could have been.

Certain units are just SO superior to others, and the difficulty can be punishing, which has you using those same units and fighting in the same way over and over.Basically, once you've won one shard, you've won them all.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Eador: Masters of the Broken World... What has it brought to us? A fine picture, a new DLC (which you will rarely use to your advantage) and a damn lot of bugs! First of all, the game is not optimized at all! Its graphics are not so great, because it's just a turn-based strategy, but is uses more resources than Skyrim until it just refuses to work. Relaunching the game may help, but I want to play, not launch it over and over again. But that's not all. Tons of bugs still occur after so many updates. Devs, are you sure you fix them? I don't see it. Just two days ago, it crashed, when I attempted to conquer a new shard and no matter how many times I reloaded the game and the save file, it was crashing in the same place. Do I have to begin it from the very beginning after so many hours of playing to get the same error again someday?! Oh, come on...New DLC... Yeah, it's fun sometimes, but that's not what I expected. It could have been much better! You just have some new units for the creatures you can make an alliance with, but if you have a troll or a minotaur, then you won't use them at all, because they are too week. And completing some tasks becomes more difficult, because, if you need to kill 10 dwarves, you'll have to kill 100 dwarves and that's not funny at all. Tastes differ, I know, but I liked the Eador: Genesis's interface more. It looked better and worked better. It was more convenient. Another thing that I did not like at all! The game has become easier! A damn lot easier compared to Eador: Genesis. When you attempt to conquer a shard, you've got 3-4 new building to acquire... When you finally conquer a shard, you get 7-8 new buildings! And how am I supposed to call that bonus? Yeah, a piece of s**t! It just ruins all the fun! You don't have to plan ahead, you don't have to choose wisely which shard you should conquer next. And in the end (if you get to it, because it can crash anytime, as I mentioned above) you have to (yes, you HAVE to) conquer EMPTY shards! And you know what? It pisses me off to waste time like that! The result: yes, Eador: Genesis is older, it doesn't have that pretty though useless DLC, it's not 3D, it doesn't have these pretty (also quite useless though) achievements in Steam, but it works well and it's more challenging, and that is why I'll choose that old beauty instead of this new piece of garbage! So, as you have already guessed, I do NOT recommend it!

												I have spent a long time playing Eador: Masters of the Broken World. I must say that this game is interesting and certainly has the "Still another turn" appeal. However, eventually I must admit: it is exceedingòy frustrating. After the few first worlds, that are fairly easy to win, the game becomes very hard. After trying in vain too many times to beat some of the enemy gods for the control of my third or fourth island in sky, I eventually felt disappointed. A game that is too easy to be interesting  becomes quickly annoying, but so does also a game that is just too difficult to be won. When I play I want to have fun. If it is too frustrating, where is the point in continuing?I may be a mediocre strategist, or just right a stupid guy, but I do not enjoy to be systematically punished. So, after too many defeats, the game is no longer on my hard disk, and I felt so well pushing the buttons to disinstall it !

number of helpful: 0 of 8 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Unfortunately, Eador: Masters of the Broken World, doesn't add anything to the fantasy 4x strategy genre.  The game feels (as in it is) really dated with mechanics, graphics, music and themes that belong at the turn of the century.  Eador would be considered a "good" game back then, but it doesn't measure up to what can be done now.  There isn't any story behind any of the game, mechanics are pretty straightforward (meaning uninspired) and don't bring anything we haven't already seen.  You will encounter odd text in tooltips, ranging from some type of humor (which comes out of nowhere) to not helpful at all. You will spend many turns pressing "next", which brings the game to another issue: performance.  Turns are pretty long, even from the start.  Considering that this isn't a very complex game to begin with, it  proves that the studio doesn't know how to optimize a game for the current era. There aren't really any options as to who you play as, where you are going or what path to take.  Overall its just a sad, flat, uninspired game that is akin to a sophmore student's project at technical school.  A "must not" buy. :/

content:
Posted: March 12
												There are so many negative reviews of this game, and I've enjoyed it so much so far (only 20 hours in but enough to get the jist of it) that I thought I'd write a short review.The are a lot of comments about how difficult this game is.  I rage quit AoW3 quite often, but I've yet to do so here.  If you're completely defeated in battle, you just resurrect after a couple of turns, repair, get more soldiers and carry on.  I'm sure as I get better at battles that will happen less often.  By the time I'd finished the last shard I was on I had a very powerful army.  Play around with different heroes and find one that fits your playstyle.To get started  I watched a couple of videos, played a couple of very short custom games to get the hang of it, and then started the campaign (it's long, and takes you to many different 'shards').I love that this game is different, so much to do, and a huge combination of choices.  It's terrific.  I haven't encountered any bugs either, but most of them were probably soon after release, which is why I bought this version of Eador and not the latest one  just yet.  Read reviews on Rock Paper Shotgun and SpaceSector.com, then add 4 years for bug fixing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												I picked up this game because Heroes VII was so terrible when it was first released - I had been pumped to grab Heroes VII, but I was driven to look at alternatives.  Eador MOTBW (along with Sorcerer King) looked like they might fit the bill.My first impression of Eador was "this is kind of like the HOMM series, but different"; that impression persists to this day.  My first attempt at playing Eador was symied by my lack of understanding of the overall campaign mission; I stopped for a while.  When I returned to it, I had done a bit of reading and the game made much more sense.Pros:  Great combat mechanics, great visuals overall, great soundtrack.Cons:  One last remaining hard-crash bug; it seems to pop up after I've loaded saved games multiple times in a single setting.  Closing out of the game and opening again always fixes it.  Autosave prevents any significant loss of progress.  The only other con is campaign strategy-related (spoiler here):  Following the "Erdu" path, it was not obvious to me that I had to go to shard after shard, finding and battling random locations containing "demons" or "demonologists" until I reached 100% ... but I eventually figured it out..Overall, it's an excellent game, and I'm certain I will go back and replay it (having multiple success paths and endings helps with this)!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												THIS GAME HAS A LOW SCORE BECAUSE IT USED TO BE COMPLETELY BROKENhaving said that, here is my review.++faction customization, as you go+broad scope of units +vastly non linear gameplay+many ways to play-limited provence interaction-no smooth transition between easy and hard-requires special privileges to avoid crashingConclusion: VERY GOODgonna be short on this one, but do you like RPGs? Do you like strategy? Do you like character building? this is the game for you. Built around forming your faction as you go rather then just making you choose from a set of premade ones the game offers many branching paths for development of both your faction in terms of religion, culture, military, and magic, aswell as for your avatar. There's plenty of hidden things and random encounters to mix things up, aswell as mercs and special weapons to buff your armies. The province interaction is very limited though, and the game suffers from the occasional bug, the difficulty curve is also a bit too steep.Also multiplayer would be good, if anyone still played this game... I give Eador a 7/10
